PERSON: Jeremiah Gumbs

HEADLINE: Jeremiah Gumbs, 91; Led Anguilla Protest

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON

 BODY:
Jeremiah Gumbs, a hotel keeper who became a hero in Anguilla when that sliver of sand upended Britain's postcolonial design for the Caribbean islands known as the Lesser Antilles, died there on Thursday, his family announced. He was 91.
 Mr. Gumbs, an institution on an island that today has a population of about 12,000 people, reached a world audience in 1967 when he went before the United Nations with the islanders' objections to a British plan that lumped Anguilla's 35 square miles into a self-governing state, St. Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla, associated with Britain. 
 Considering the 70 miles of blue waters between Anguilla, the northernmost of the Leeward Islands, and the new authorities in St. Kitts, not to mention the many different flags that flew on the islands in between, like St. Martin and St. Barthelemy, the Anguillans balked. 
 ''After 300 years of neglect as a British colony,'' Mr. Gumbs told the United Nations, ''the people feel they are able to take care of their own affairs.'' Indeed, he said, Anguillans wanted independence.
 The people of Anguilla voted for it, 1,813 to 5, but Britain did not recognize either the referendum or Mr. Gumbs as a leader of the secessionist movement. But a special United Nations subcommittee on colonialism listened to his formal arguments for Anguilla. 
 It was a ''natural paradise,'' Mr. Gumbs said of the island, but had been left undeveloped under British rule, without running water, electricity, phones or a decent road. (A new highway, built with European aid, has recently been named for Mr. Gumbs.)
 The British protested United Nations involvement, while other Caribbean commonwealth islands sought to mediate. 
 Britain asserted that the island was ''completely dominated by a gangster-type element,'' referring to Mr. Gumbs and the chosen leader of the rebellion, James Ronald Webster. It sent a troop of London's Metropolitan Police force to keep order and stop the secession movement. 
 But efforts to patch the link to St. Kitts failed. In the end, Anguilla got part of what it wanted, becoming a self-governing British dependent territory with its own elected officials, an arrangement codified in 1971 and brought up to date with Anguilla's new Constitution in 1982.
 Jeremiah Gumbs was born in Anguilla, the youngest of nine children; his mother was a baker and his father a fisherman. He started school in Anguilla, but economic hardship drove him as a boy to work the cane fields in the Dominican Republic. Starting at age 15, he worked for two years in oil refineries in Aruba and Curacao before returning to Anguilla to teach himself tailoring.
 At 25, he went to live with a sister in Brooklyn and took night classes at City College on a scholarship. He hoped to become a dentist, but was drafted into the Army in 1941 and was given American citizenship at the time.
 After the war, he married Lydia Gibbs of Perth Amboy, N.J., and, using his G.I. Bill money, trained as a furnace installer. He started his own company in Perth Amboy, Gumbs Fuelers, and made a success of it.
 When he took Lydia to show her Anguilla, it was she who planted the idea for another venture -- tourism on the island's untouched beaches. They bought 14 acres, later doubling the amount, and in 1959 started building Anguilla's first beach resort with their own hands.
 They rented the first rooms in 1962, opening what has become the Rendezvous Bay Hotel and Villas, a cornerstone of the island's growing tourism industry. 
 As a businessman with local roots and a civic leader acquainted with the ways of the world, Jeremiah Gumbs became a natural choice to serve as the island's roving ambassador during the Anguillan revolution of 1967-69.
 He managed the hotel until about five years ago and remained a jovial host after that.
 Lydia Gumbs died about three years ago. Jeremiah Gumbs is survived by three sons, J. Alan, the managing director and owner of the Rendezvous Bay, Clyde, of Atlanta, and Duane, of Edison, N.J.; a daughter, Una, of Edison and Anguilla; and seven grandchildren.

LENGTH: 927 words

HEADLINE: Iraqis Unclear About Answers, but Clearly Weary of War

BYLINE: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

DATELINE: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 9 

 BODY:
The Happy Time restaurant sounds like an improbable place for Iraqis to discuss the turmoil and strife of a growing guerrilla war against American-led troops occupying their country.
 But one year after the fall of Saddam Hussein, Aseel Suheil and her friends sat in gathering darkness in the restaurant's courtyard and expressed disappointment in life in Iraq, fearing the prospect of more conflict as Shiite and Sunni militias battle foreign forces.
 ''The only reason we come to this restaurant is because it's close to where we live,'' Ms. Suheil said. ''We are afraid of going out these days because of car bombs, and every young man seems to carry a gun now.'' 
 The Mahdi Army -- the militia of the anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr -- is said by American officials to stand at 4,000 to 6,000 members. And while many Iraqis say they support the idea of ridding their country of the military occupation now, they are not all Sadr followers.
 Many say they do not see a clear solution.
 ''I'm a Shiite, but I do not want the Mahdi Army,'' said Ms. Suheil's friend, a Shiite Muslim named Nahla Abdel Wahid, as they sat in the Happy Time. ''They are too extreme and backward.''
 ''They would never let us go out in the streets, or sit here with our hair down,'' Ms. Suheil added. Some Shiite followers of Mr. Sadr want an Islamic government guided by senior clerics. ''But the American forces should get out,'' she said. ''They just attract gunfire now. They should leave it to us.''
 The Mahdi Army and Sunnis fighting in Falluja and Ramadi are loosely allied by a common purpose, which they say is to rid the country of foreign forces. Shiite and Sunni Muslims form the majority of Iraq's population.
 Few people say they have much trust in the American-backed Iraqi Governing Council, complaining that it is not elected. They are also mistrustful of the interim constitution and of the promise that their lives will be improved when the United States returns sovereignty to the Iraqis in a largely ceremonial transfer in June. 
 But there is little appetite for more fighting in a country that has been embroiled in the Iran-Iraq war, the 1991 war in Kuwait, and then the American-led war last year. In that sense, Iraqis feel pushed into more instability.
 ''More people will just pour into the streets if they try to arrest Sadr,'' said Abed Jumaa, a 38-year-old war veteran, as he sat in a cafe in the Zayona neighborhood here, bustling with shoppers and diners. ''But we are tired of conflict.''
 His friend, Sabah Anwar, has a deep scar across his head, which he said was a wound from the Iran-Iraq war of the 1980's. He said the guerrillas fighting the United States had served as a sort of rallying point for Iraqis, giving them common ground. ''We have decided we should all say we are behind Sadr,'' he said. ''We thank the United States only on one point -- for getting rid of Saddam Hussein. After that we have been left on our own with nothing tangible.''
 On the Dura highway traveling south of Baghdad to the Shiite city of Karbala, columns of American tanks and Humvees shared the lanes with Iraqis in civilian cars on a pilgrimage. Soldiers sat in jump seats above the vehicles, their heavy machine guns spiked skyward or fixed pointedly at the civilian traffic, apparently as a precaution against drive-by attacks.
 The column's presence was a reminder of the religious aspect of the quandary American forces face in the cities of Karbala and Najaf. At a time when the Mahdi Army is growing bolder, the military has had to adopt a hands-off approach to the two cities out of respect for the Shiite religious pilgrimage, which draws millions this weekend.
 ''The Americans have no right to interfere with our freedom of movement,'' said a cleric, Sheik Niseem al-Abadi, sitting in a tent on the roadside where charities gave away food and water to pilgrims en route to Karbala. ''There had better not be checkpoints or attempts to impede the pilgrims.'' Like many of Iraq's clerics, he suggested that what Iraq needed was a government that reflected Islamic principles.
 An economics teacher, Talal Abdel-Hadi, said he was opposed to the occupation but was not convinced that the Mahdi Army represented the interests of Iraq's 24 million people. He and his friends, sitting with him in his garden near the square where Saddam Hussein's statue was toppled last year, said that what Iraq needs now are elections, rather than a militia force, to define the way the country is led.
 ''We are an educated people, and many of his followers are not cultured,'' he said. ''Anyone who is elected by the people and can truly serve us is what we need now.''
 ''As for the Americans, they have technology, and we have ideas,'' Mr. Abdel-Hadi said. ''Maybe one day we can cooperate away from the language of violence.''
 Some Iraqis suggest that the United Nations should take a more active role, and even send peacekeepers for stability, rather than an occupying military force.
 Such was the view of Kathim Abdel Wahid, 50, a former cobbler, who stood over his daughter in the hospital in the Baghdad neighborhood of Sadr City, where American forces in tanks battled Mahdi Army fighters this week after they tried to seize control of Iraqi police stations.
 He held up an X-ray showing a bullet lodged in the girl's cheek.
 ''What is this all about that innocent people are getting shot at in the streets?'' he asked. ''What kind of society do we have?'' The time has come for American forces to yield to a neutral force, like one attached to the United Nations.''

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Americas: Brazil: Sale Of Airline Stake

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
The Brazilian airline TAM plans to sell a 20 percent stake in Brazil and the United States within a year in a bid to raise as much as $150 million to increase working capital, the chief executive, Marco Bologna, said. The carrier will sell new preferred shares, expecting to attract investors as Brazil's economy recovers. Domestic air travel is expected to grow 7 percent this year, according to Mr. Bologna's estimate. TAM, which accounts for a third of the country's domestic air travel, plans to sell the shares from September and March next year, Mr. Bologna said.

LENGTH: 1436 words

HEADLINE: Built With Steel, Perhaps, but Greased With Pork

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: KETCHIKAN, Alaska, April 8 

 BODY:
Even by the standards of Alaska, the land where schemes and dreams come for new life, two bridges approved under the national highway bill passed by the House last week are monuments to the imagination.
 One, here in Ketchikan, would be among the biggest in the United States: a mile long, with a top clearance of 200 feet from the water -- 80 feet higher than the Brooklyn Bridge and just 20 feet short of the Golden Gate Bridge. It would connect this economically depressed, rain-soaked town of 7,845 people to an island that has about 50 residents and the area's airport, which offers six flights a day (a few more in summer). It could cost about $200 million.
 The other bridge would span an inlet for nearly two miles to tie Anchorage to a port that has a single regular tenant and almost no homes or businesses. It would cost up to $2 billion. 
 These ''bridges to nowhere,'' as critics have dubbed the two costliest of the high-priority projects in the six-year, $275 billion House bill, are one reason Republicans are fighting among themselves in shaping the nation's transportation spending.
 President Bush has threatened to use his first veto against any measure that emerges from a House-Senate conference with a cost of more than $256 billion. (The Senate version, passed in February, calls for $318 billion and includes neither of the projects, though their champion on Capitol Hill voices certainty that they will be added in conference.) Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, has described the legislation as so laden with pork as to betray the party's principles.
 But if this is pork, the Republican behind the House bill says bring it on, with extra fat. Representative Don Young, Alaska's lone member of the House, where he is chairman of the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee, is already known as Mr. Concrete but would like to wear another title as well.
 ''I'd like to be a little oinker, myself,'' Mr. Young told a Republican lunch crowd here, taking mock offense at the suggestion that Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, directs more pork to their state than he does. ''If he's the chief porker, I'm upset.''
 When asked why a town with one main road, a dwindling population and virtually nowhere to drive to needs a bridge to rival the world's great spans, people here inevitably respond with two words: Don Young. Mr. Young, mindful that the highway bill comes up for renewal only once every six years or so, and that the House Republican Conference imposes three-term limits on committee chairmanships, says the opportunity to pour so many federal dollars into his home state comes once in a lifetime, and should be seized.
 ''If you don't do it now, when are you going to do it?'' he said at the luncheon. ''This is the time to take advantage of the position I'm in, along with Senator Stevens.''
 He said he would support an increase in the federal tax on gasoline -- a ''user fee,'' he called it -- to pay for even more projects than were included in the newly passed bill.
 People here in Ketchikan, in far southeastern Alaska off the coast of British Columbia, are grateful for Mr. Young's efforts, and they can certainly use the 600 or so jobs that a vast government works project would bring. A veneer mill, supported by $17 million in federal aid, lies empty and rusting, in search of an owner. The town's biggest job provider, a pulp mill, shut down in 1997.
 But as a transportation solution, the Ketchikan bridge is seen as something of a joke. It would replace a five-minute ferry crossing.
 ''Everyone knows it's just a boondoggle that we're getting because we have a powerful congressman,'' said Mike Sallee, 57, whose mother homesteaded here and who now runs a small timber operation. ''That ferry of ours has been pretty darn reliable.''
 In public hearings on the bridge plan, officials heard few complaints about the ferry service. The ferry crosses every half-hour in winter and every 15 minutes in summer, when there are two boats available and a third on call. The crossing one day this week, from the time a visitor picked up his bags at the airport to his reaching town, took less than 10 minutes -- and that included a wait for the ferry to arrive and dock at the island. 
 The Gravina Island Access Bridge, as the project is called, has been given a Golden Fleece award by Taxpayers for Common Sense, a budget watchdog based in Washington.
 ''It's a gold-plated bridge to nowhere,'' said Keith Ashdown, a spokesman for the group. ''At a time when we have bridges and roads crumbling around the United States, and traffic congestion worse than ever, why build a $200 million project that will serve only a few hundred people?''
 Mr. Young, whose bill has broad bipartisan support, speaks with passion of how traffic congestion has robbed the average American of 68 hours a year in lost time. But he says taking care of Alaska is just as important.
 ''If I had not done fairly well for our state,'' he said, ''I'd be ashamed of myself.''
 As for the merits of the Ketchikan proposal, he said, ''It's a bridge to somewhere.'' That somewhere is an island with a few miles of dirt roads, an unlogged sliver of the nation's biggest national forest. Mr. Young hopes the bridge will spur development in a part of Alaska where, though rain is measured by the foot (an average of more than 13 feet a year), cruise ships bring nearly a million tourists annually.
 The nation's highway statute gets its money from a trust fund financed by the 18.4-cent-a-gallon federal tax that Americans pay on gasoline. Every time the legislation is renewed, lawmakers load it with special projects for their districts, called earmarks. Alaskans get nearly $7 back for every dollar they put into the fund.
 In all, the current House bill would give Alaska $540 million in earmarks, including down payments of $120 million for the Ketchikan bridge and $200 million for the one at Anchorage. Those two costs alone are more than the total for earmarked projects in all of 41 other states, according to an analysis by Taxpayers for Common Sense.
 Mr. Young said Alaska had been late to the federal table -- it did not join the Union until 1959 -- and needed to play catch-up. With his position as chairman of the House transportation committee, and with Mr. Stevens driving appropriations in the Senate, the state can muscle through most of the road projects it dreams up, he said.
 ''It's not a good way to legislate, although I got a lot of stuff in it,'' Mr. Young told The Anchorage Daily News in December. ''I mean I stuffed it like a turkey.''
 The bridge in Anchorage would cross Knik Arm, which is clogged by ice blocks the size of cars for much of the year, and connect the city to an undeveloped area around Port MacKenzie. In their proposal, state officials said it was needed for domestic security and to ''coordinate operations'' between the Port of Anchorage and the MacKenzie port, which has only one permanent tenant. Promoters of the bridge now say it is needed to stimulate housing and commercial development as well.
 Here in Ketchikan, a simple bridge to the north of the one now envisioned would have spanned a gap of only a quarter-mile between the airport and town, and at only a fraction of the cost. But it was judged too close to the airport for pilot safety. 
 Another idea was a bridge with a clearance of 120 feet rather than the 200 now planned. But that would have forced cruise ships, the only growth industry in town, to take a different approach to port. After cruise lines threatened to cut some dockings, the most expensive design offered became the plan of choice.
 It calls for a span that will be longer than the George Washington Bridge, over the Hudson River, and will connect to Gravina Island through a middle island. Builders will be cutting into the flank of a mountain to anchor it.
 Yet the bridge may make for a longer trip to the airport, people here say. Anyone driving from Ketchikan to catch a plane will have to head south of town, move past a main drag frequently clogged with tourists, ascend a mountain, cross the mile-long bridge westbound, then circle north around the back of Gravina Island to reach the airport. In addition, the airport will have to build a parking structure, at an estimated cost of $11 million.
 ''The funny thing, when that big bridge is done, it will take more time to get to the airport than it does now on our little ferry,'' said Dale Collins, a mariner who heads the ship pilots association here. ''But it sure will be big. It's unbelievable, the size of that bridge.''


GRAPHIC: Photo: Tiny Ketchikan, in foreground, would be linked by a bridge to a mountainous island a mile away. (Photo by Associated Press for The New York Times)(pg. A1)Map of Alaska highlighting Anchorage and Ketchikan -- Anchorage and Ketchikan: beneficiaries of a lawmaker's power. (pg. A12)

LENGTH: 1703 words

HEADLINE: As Bush Ends Money Drive, Kerry Goes On

BYLINE: By GLEN JUSTICE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
President Bush held his last planned fund-raising event for his re-election campaign on Monday, having collected almost twice as much money as he did in 2000.
 By contrast, Senator John Kerry pushed ahead with what will be one of the busiest fund-raising months of his campaign. He is still personally calling donors and attending major events in a dozen cities this month as he seeks to compete with the president's expansive financial network.
 Mr. Bush's aides said they saw no need to continue major events because they had met their long-held goal, and had always planned to turn their attention to campaigning at this point in the race. Mr. Bush raised more than $180 million through March, exceeding his goal by $10 million. Mr. Kerry, who has raised $79 million, is taking advantage of an outpouring of Democratic support after emerging as his party's presumptive nominee. 
 The differences in their fund-raising underscore the sharply different missions of the Bush and Kerry campaigns. While the Bush operation can afford to run television commercials that try to define Mr. Kerry and is sending the president to campaign events, his opponent is busy taking in cash.
 On Thursday, for example, Mr. Kerry raised more than $1 million in Chicago, then picked up $500,000 for the Democratic National Committee over breakfast on Friday. Next week, he will make six stops, including a big-money fund-raiser in New York on Wednesday. The gala for roughly 2,200 people at the Sheraton Hotel and Towers could raise enough to rival the $4 million Mr. Bush collected in the city last summer, Kerry fund-raisers said.
 Afterward, Mr. Kerry, who is from Massachusetts, will appear at a low-dollar event at the Crobar nightclub, where young supporters will mingle with celebrities like Tom DeLonge, the singer-guitarist for the band Blink-182.
 Mr. Bush has held 55 fund-raisers in 32 states, but he has been able to wrap up such events (though he will continue to raise some money through the Internet and direct mail) because he has a sophisticated financial network, something Mr. Kerry is still developing. Because of those deep financial resources, and no primary competition, the president had $110 million on hand at the start of March. Mr. Kerry had $2.4 million on hand after an expensive and competitive primary season.
 The contrasts in the networks offer a window into the industries and individuals that Mr. Bush and Mr. Kerry have relied on for financial support over their careers.
 Both networks started as homegrown operations, with Mr. Bush turning to his Texas roots in 2000, just as Mr. Kerry relied on members of his brother's law firm and other Massachusetts companies earlier in the 2004 race. But campaign finance experts say that the need to gather increasing millions has forced both camps to vastly expand their networks as they search for contributions, which are now limited to $2,000 per person under the McCain-Feingold campaign finance law.
 ''You just keep building your base, there's no other way to do it,'' said Louis Susman, Mr. Kerry's national finance chairman. ''It's got to continue to grow.''
 One result is that both candidates are seeing vast changes to their roster of financial supporters. The ante has been raised further: the expansion comes at a time when both candidates have been free to raise and spend without limits in the primary because neither accepted public financing and the spending caps that come with it.
 The changes and growth are most obvious for Mr. Bush, who has expanded his list of top donors beyond the Texas firms and industries that he started with four years ago. Now the worlds of accounting, investment, insurance and financial services dominate his list of top donors.
 That change is embodied in PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting giant that emerged in March reports as the top source of money for Mr. Bush's career after employees gave more than $607,000. It narrowly edged out longtime supporters like the MBNA Corporation and Enron, where employees had also given hundreds of thousands, according to the Center for Public Integrity, which tracks top donors.
 Several company executives at the accounting firm signed on to raise money, feeding campaign fund-raisers from Dallas to Washington. For example, former Representative Bill Archer of Texas, once the chairman of the tax-writing Ways and Means Committee and now an employee in the firm's Washington office, has helped. In November, he opened his Virginia home for a fund-raiser where guests paid to $2,000 to hear Andrew H. Card Jr., the president's chief of staff. 
 ''It's like any group of businesspeople,'' said one Washington employee at the firm. ''They are looking around for the best things they can do for themselves and their business interests.''
 For now, Mr. Kerry's view of the financial landscape is more limited. The senator from Massachusetts still counts employees at the Boston law firm where his brother works -- Mintz, Levin, Cohn, Ferris, Glovsky & Popeo -- as his top source of money during his career, according to the center. However, contributions have poured in since he became the presumptive nominee, $38 million in March alone, and the money is likely to reshape a list of top career supporters still heavy with law firms and home-state companies.
 ''Once you become the nominee, the money comes in from everywhere,'' said Francis Bellotti, a former attorney general for Massachusetts and a lawyer at Mintz, Levin who has long supported Mr. Kerry. ''This is a national thing now.''
 That has been the case for Mr. Bush for some time. The groundwork for his national network, and his presidential run, was partly laid in 1998 when Mr. Bush's friend and confidante, James B. Francis Jr., hit upon an idea: Create a class of high-dollar fund-raiser who would receive special recognition from the campaign.
 At that moment, the Pioneers were born, a group of 241 people who each raised $100,000. Almost a third were from Texas, where many had supported Mr. Bush as governor.
 ''It was the same people that grew up with him,'' said Nancy Kinder, a longtime friend of Mr. Bush who has raised hundreds of thousands for his campaigns. But in this year's race, the operation is now selling an administration with a record on terrorism and taxes, instead of introducing a Republican governor with a famous last name.
 This time around, hundreds of new people have signed on as Pioneers and Rangers, a new class of $200,000 fund-raiser created for this campaign, bringing the number of six-figure fund-raisers to more than 450. More now come from Florida than from Texas.
 Of course, major fund-raising also brings major criticism. Since he arrived in the White House, Mr. Bush has been accused by Democrats of catering to the corporate interests that support him.
 Early on, the criticism focused on the oil and gas industry, where both Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney had worked. More recently, Democratic attacks have focused on economic policies like cuts to taxes on dividends and capital gains, as well as plans to introduce private investment into the Social Security system. Critics say such policies are a bald appeal to financial companies that benefit from such changes.
 Mr. Kerry, in turn, draws criticism from Republicans who say he is hypocritical in pledging not to accept money from political action committees and criticizing corporate lobbyists, noting that he has taken money from lobbyists and corporate interests just as any other candidate has. The Republican National Committee derides him as ''Cash and Kerry.''
 Mr. Kerry's organization, of course, hopes to see its network expand and change just as Mr. Bush's did. As of March, he had 182 major fund-raisers, but only a third had raised $100,000 or more, though the campaign is signing up new fund-raisers all the time.
 The Kerry network was created over four Senate races, and in that time Mr. Kerry developed a reputation as a prolific fund-raiser. In the late 1980's, he headed the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, which is responsible for electing Senate Democrats. 
 ''The whole network was not built overnight,'' said Peter Maroney, a fund-raiser who has worked for Mr. Kerry for seven years. ''It was developed and worked on and took a lot of time and energy and travel.''
 Mr. Kerry was often personally involved. Owen Byrd, a lawyer from California, found that out firsthand when he began raising money for him last year. Mr. Byrd was washing dishes in his Palo Alto home when his cell phone rang. ''Hey man,'' a voice said. ''It's John Kerry. How are you doing?''
 Mr. Byrd had agreed to hold a $30,000 fund-raiser, tiny by presidential standards, but apparently enough to warrant a call from Mr. Kerry, who gently prodded him to raise as much as possible. ''It worked,'' Mr. Byrd said. ''He didn't pound me or hound me, but he left me motivated.''
 The expansion of Mr. Kerry's network intensified when he decided to run for president. He and his top aides raised millions for his 2002 Senate re-election, despite the lack of a tough challenger. They also traveled the country recruiting new Democratic fund-raisers and sources of money.
 One new source was the employees at the law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. They were not major contributors to his Senate races but have moved up Mr. Kerry's list of top career donors based on their work in this race. The firm has no fewer than three partners who have each raised at least $100,000. 
 Another law firm, Piper Rudnick, has four Kerry fund-raisers in its ranks.
 These days, Mr. Kerry is raking in tens of millions over the Internet and completing a fund-raising tour that began in March. ''We have to be creative in keeping the momentum going,'' Mr. Maroney said. ''That's the key to successful fund-raising.''
 Mr. Kerry will eventually stop raising money because both nominees are expected to receive $75 million apiece in public money after the national conventions this summer to finance their general election drives.
 But for now, the advantage is still with Mr. Bush. Of Mr. Kerry's top 10 sources of money through February, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, half of them had given more to the president.

HEADLINE: Asian Stocks Fall on Fears of Violence in Iraq

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Asian stocks fell, led by Sony and Samsung Electronics, on concern that violence in Iraq and the threat of terrorist attacks would slow global economic expansion. 
 In Japan, the Nikkei 225 stock average slumped 1.6 percent, to 11,897.51, its biggest drop in six weeks. 
The Kospi index in South Korea lost 1.3 percent, to 905.44, its first slide in seven sessions. 
 Japan Airlines System led declines in Asian airline stocks on concern the threat of terrorism would dent travel demand. 
 Benchmarks in Taiwan and China declined while indexes in Malaysia and Thailand were little changed. 
 Stock markets in Australia, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, New Zealand, the Philippines, Singapore and Sri Lanka were closed for Easter. 
 Sony lost 1.8 percent, to 4,400 yen. Samsung Electronics, South Korea's largest company by market value and its biggest exporter, fell 1.7 percent, to 595,000 won. 
 Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, the supplier of made-to-order computer chips that counts on the United States for three-quarters of its revenue, shed 1.6 percent, to 60 New Taiwan dollars. 
 The Topix air transport index in Japan slid 2.8 percent. Japan Airlines, Asia's largest carrier by sales, dropped 3.1 percent, to 344 yen. All Nippon Airways, the region's second biggest, slipped 2.5 percent, to 351 yen. Korean Air shed 2.4 percent, to 18,500 won. 
 The Shanghai composite index, which tracks the larger of China's two stock markets, lost 2.4 percent, to 1,727.35, on concern that the government might raise lending rates to cool accelerating economic growth. Industrial production rose 19.4 percent in March, the fastest pace in more than a year, the government said yesterday. 
 China United Telecommunications, the owner of a large cellular network, fell 1.5 percent, to 4.51 yuan.

HEADLINE: U.S. Relies on U.N. to Solve Problems of Power Transfer

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL and WARREN HOGE; Douglas Jehl reported from Washington for this article and Warren Hoge from the United Nations.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 9 

 BODY:
The State Department on Friday dismissed as ''highly speculative'' the idea that increased fighting in Iraq might force a delay in a planned transfer of power to Iraqis by June 30.
 But in light of the anti-American insurrection, senior Bush administration officials said the United States was relying increasingly on the United Nations to put an international stamp on efforts to resolve differences among Iraqis on the makeup of an interim government.
 ''In view of the violence, I think the wisdom of that approach has been validated,'' a senior State Department official said of an effort that is counting heavily on a United Nations envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, to win agreement from Iraqis on a transfer plan.
 Despite the mounting difficulties in Iraq, President Bush and his top aides have insisted all week that they remain more committed than ever to the June 30 deadline, which the administration set last fall. Senior administration officials say the rebellion has only strengthened their conviction that to cede political power to Iraqis on schedule is the right thing to do. 
 ''We are focusing on confronting those distinct and, I would suggest, isolated elements that seek to derail the political process through the use of violence to advance their parochial interests,'' the State Department spokesman, Adam Ereli, said Friday. ''We're confronting that, and we want to return the process and give the process back to the Iraqi people, those Iraqi people who favor dialogue over force. And we think that we'll be successful there.''
 Mr. Brahimi will be ''the pivotal agent'' in trying to rescue the imperiled effort to forge a transitional government acceptable to Iraq's main political groups, a senior Bush administration official said this week. By contrast, the official described an American envoy, Robert Blackwill, a deputy national security adviser now coordinating Iraq policy for the administration, as ''a political matchmaker'' in the process.
 Mr. Brahimi has been in Baghdad since Sunday, on his second mission this year to assess the political situation and advise the Iraqis on how to proceed with the June 30 transition.
 He met with many groups this week despite the surge of violence, according to Stephane Dujarric, a United Nations spokesman. It is not known when he will end his mission and report back to headquarters.
 In an interview, Munir Akram, Pakistan's ambassador to the United Nations, said he believed that Mr. Brahimi was exploring three options -- turning over sovereignty on June 30 to the existing 25-member Iraqi Governing Council, giving power to an expanded council that would add members to become more broadly representative than the present one, or calling a meeting of tribal leaders like the loya jirga gathering in Kabul last year when Mr. Brahimi was the United Nations' envoy to Afghanistan.
 ''I think the third option is eroding because of the time factor, and the second option, the expanded council, is the most likely,'' he said.
 Mr. Akram said the Security Council was united in the belief that the June 30 date for transition of power ought to be met. ''Everyone's agreed on June 30 -- we have the sense that this is a good thing, as much for the Iraqis as for the U.S.,'' he said.
 In public remarks in recent days, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld and other top officials have argued that the violence in Iraq was being fueled in part by the approaching deadline. They have portrayed the attacks by Shiite and Sunni radicals as intended to sidetrack a process intended to put power in the hands of more moderate Iraqis.
 While acknowledging that winning agreement on a schedule for a new transfer plan remains a challenging task, administration officials said this week that they saw it as an increasingly important goal.
 ''It is our sense that the key to stability in Iraqi is empowering Iraqis politically and economically, and the transfer of sovereignty is the symbol of that,'' a senior State Department official said. Administration officials said they were still holding out hope that Mr. Brahimi might forge a consensus on some plan within the next month.
 Mr. Brahimi's method, as described by both United Nations and American officials, is to push Iraqis toward consensus without seeming to impose his will on them. A poker-faced former foreign minister of Algeria, Mr. Brahimi, 70, is known for keeping any sign of his own preferences to himself and building trust among feuding Muslim factions.
 The United Nations is wary of appearing to be doing the work of the allied occupiers, and Mr. Brahimi guards his independence closely, particularly because it is well known that the White House urged Secretary General Kofi Annan to give him this assignment.
 Iraq dominated conversation at a lunch at the State Department on Thursday between Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Senators Richard G. Lugar, Republican of Indiana, and Joseph R. Biden, Democrat of Delaware, who have suggested in recent days that it might now be a mistake to proceed with the transfer as scheduled, officials said. The senators are the chairman and senior Democrat of the Foreign Relations Committee.
 ''If there's an expectation that Brahimi is a miracle worker, that's a huge expectation,'' a spokesman for Mr. Lugar, Andy Fisher, said after the meeting.

HEADLINE: Kerry Says Policy in Iraq Compromises U.S. Safety

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 9 

 BODY:
Senator John Kerry said Friday that the Bush administration's approach to Iraq was ''gridlocked by its own ideology and its own arrogance'' and asserted that he had more experience than President Bush in handling national security.
 Asked by a television reporter here how he would respond to voters who worried about changing commanders in chief during the war on terror, Mr. Kerry, a decorated Vietnam veteran, cited his two decades of experience on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
 ''I'm not untested in that kind of leadership role,'' Mr. Kerry, the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, said. ''I think you measure leadership by the lifetime of experience. And I bring more experience in military affairs, foreign policy and national affairs than George Bush even has today, more experience.'' 
 He said, ''George Bush, in my judgment, has run a foreign policy that has made us less safe than we ought to be in the aftermath of 9/11.''
 Mr. Kerry made the comment as he talked about the economy here and met with the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Barack Obama, the Democratic nominee for a Senate seat here, to help devise his strategy to inspire African-Americans to go to the polls in the fall.
 But as has occurred most of this week, Mr. Kerry was asked repeatedly about the deteriorating situation in Iraq while he was trying to focus on the economy.
 ''This administration has been gridlocked by its own ideology and its own arrogance,'' Mr. Kerry said at a fund-raising breakfast Friday morning with two dozen donors, who gave him $100,000. ''We can succeed but, boy, it's a lot tougher than it has to be.''
 Don Imus, the television and radio personality, also interviewed the senator on Friday and asked several questions about Iraq.
 Mr. Kerry said the United States should show ''a little bit of humility'' and go to the United Nations and build a coalition of allies to take over the policing and reconstruction of Iraq.
 The Bush campaign attacked Mr. Kerry for criticizing the president on the war and said he offered no real plan of his own.
 ''Instead of showing the world and the enemies of freedom that America stands firmly behind the effort in Iraq, and is committed to victory,'' said Nicolle Devenish, a Bush campaign spokeswoman, in a statement. ''John Kerry has made the political calculation to rail against the war on terror at every stop on the campaign trail without offering any credible alternative.'' 
 Later, Mr. Jackson said he told Mr. Kerry in a private meeting Friday that he should try to move the public debate off the topics that the White House wants to talk about -- ''taxes and terror,'' as he put it -- and broaden the discussion to matters like education, health care, poverty and voting rights.
 Mr. Jackson met with Mr. Kerry for half an hour after Mr. Kerry held an economic forum at a job training center in West Chicago. Mr. Jackson said in a telephone interview after the meeting that he and Mr. Kerry shared the belief that black voters needed to be convinced to ''vote their hopes, not their despair,'' and that white voters needed to ''vote their economic needs, not their fears.''
 Mr. Jackson said he supported Mr. Kerry and had talked to him throughout the campaign, but added, ''I've not chosen to have some grand endorsement plan.'' Similarly, he said, his son, Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr., who backed Howard Dean during the primaries, also supported Mr. Kerry now but would probably not make a formal endorsement.
 Mr. Obama, who if elected would become the only black member of the Senate, said blacks were ''extraordinarily motivated right now'' because ''they are still mad about Florida,'' referring to the 2000 presidential election, when many minority voters said they were disenfranchised. ''But my task is to galvanize that vote,'' he told reporters.
 Mr. Obama, a state senator from Chicago, leads his Republican rival, Jack Ryan, by 19 percentage points in the most recent poll. While Mr. Obama demurred when asked if Mr. Kerry could ride his coattails in Illinois in November, Mr. Kerry told donors at a $1 million fund-raising dinner here Thursday night that he intended to do just that.
 Mr. Obama said that Democrats wanted to nail down Illinois early for Mr. Kerry so he could devote his attention to other swing states.
 ''We're hopeful that we can take Illinois out of play sometime during the summer,'' Mr. Obama said. ''If we do our job over the next three months, we'd like John Kerry to come back here primarily to raise money and say hello and say thank you.''

HEADLINE: The Time Has Come to Ride and Beep and Laugh Again

BYLINE: By ERIN ST. JOHN KELLY

 BODY:
To those who whiz by it on the Belt Parkway, Nellie Bly Amusement Park in Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, looks like a mom-and-pop operation. But it isn't. It's only a mom operation. Gena Romano, 48, the single mother of Andrew, 5, owns and operates the park with help from her mother, Antoinette, 76. 
 What does spring mean to Gena Romano? ''My one word? Stress.'' What do Easter and Passover mean? Not as unusual: candy, family, prayer for nice weather. The difference for Ms. Romano is that this is her big opening weekend. Showtime at Nellie Bly. 
 ''Every year we turn on the water and there are always surprises, like with a country house,'' she said while walking around the park on a recent cold, gray March day. ''The big push now is to hire, train and inspect. After that we work on the details.'' Ms. Romano, who has a master's degree in fine arts, will touch up her painting on the house of horror at a quieter time.
 Sandbags are stuffed into the Frog Hopper ride's big midcroak mouths in a maximum load test. At the Dumbo ride, the pink and yellow elephants are on the asphalt waiting for electrical work, while the blue, orange and red ones that have passed inspection are already hung, the cold wind blowing into their giant ears. A handful of workers are replacing fluorescent bulbs at the kart track; others are releasing the Cool Climb rock from its blue tarpaulin winterizing cocoon.
 Nellie Bly Amusement Park is one of 420 in the country, 40 in New York State and 6 in the city, according to the International Association of Amusement Parks and Attractions' membership rolls. ''Smaller, noncorporate parks are alive and well,'' said Beth Robertson, the association's vice president for communications, ''but truly family-owned parks handed down through generations are much less common than even 20 years ago.'' 
 Ms. Romano's father, Eugene, and two uncles, Alfred and Henry, founded the park in 1963 in the parking lot of a driving range that occupied the site. (They named the park on a whim after a pioneering journalist of the late 19th century.) The Romanos lease the park's three acres, on the bay side of the Belt Parkway, from the city.
 The amusement industry took in $10.3 billion in 2003, Ms. Robertson said, but ''it has to look at new populations and really had to be creative and clever to have people return.'' Ms. Romano sees that as her imperative, too.
 Like all amusement parks, Nellie Bly must compete with growing entertainment options. Places like the Brooklyn Museum of Art, the Liberty Science Center in New Jersey and even the Brooklyn Botanic Garden vie for the same families. The park has traditionally had friendly competition with its neighbors at Coney Island -- Astroland and Dino's Wonder Wheel.
 ''You could never start a business like this again; it could really only be a corporation,'' said Ms. Romano, who noted that she took out a loan each winter to run the place, then repaid it. ''It's become a very costly thing to run.''
 Technically, Ms. Romano inherited the park when her father died in 2000, but she can barely remember not being in training for the position. ''I've done everything except for detailed mechanics on the rides,'' she said. ''I would say my best talent is cotton-candy-making.''
 In her father's day, she said, the park had an electrician on staff but now she pays for the work by the job, for about $30 per hour. She uses plumbers, carpenters and mechanics the same way. ''There's only so much we can charge by the ride,'' she said. ''We're not Disney World.'' This year rides will average $1.70 to $4. 
 Ms. Romano sees her job as finding ''the right mix'' of labor, equipment and rental costs while expanding what she offers families. She also tries to keep the park viable for the future, for her son, Andrew, to inherit. ''He wants to call it Andrew's World now.'' 
 She is excited by her newest contribution to that mix: the Whirl Wind, an $85,000 swing ride for 9- to 13-year-olds that she bought during the winter. ''It's not too crazy,'' she said. ''I don't want to turn them upside down and shake them.'' 
 Nellie Bly gets 150,000 visitors a year, Ms. Romano estimates. But that is only a guess, as she does not charge admission at the gate. She also estimates that she holds 800 birthday parties a year -- recently, even one for a man deep into his 50's. ''I see everybody I know once a year. Even if they've moved out, if they have children, they bring them here.''
 Winters are slow at Nellie Bly; the park goes into hibernation in October when it gets too cold for visitors to enjoy squirting water guns into gaping clown mouths for prizes or swirling on the Tilt-A-Whirl.
 From a summer season employment high of about 100, the park empties out to all but about 8 (depending on projects under way). 
 As spring approaches, Ms. Romano starts to wake the place up. Every year, she must play host to all kinds of inspectors. Spring means stocking the prizes, booking the birthday parties, lubing the karts, cleaning the batting cages and the miniature golf course, and hiring staff. ''This year a lot of adults applied for jobs, and I think it's reflective of the economy,'' she said. ''These are people with families.''
 The 22 rides, the fire system for concession stands, the arcade and the games all have to be licensed. The llama, four goats, one sheep, four rabbits and assorted fowl on her petting farm get a visit from a federal animal inspector. ''I'm an animal lover,'' she said, ''so he's the one I'm actually friendly with.''
 Ms. Romano smiles and laughs often while talking about her life's work. She tries to create an oasis of happiness. ''People sit in front of screens too much and don't talk to each other. I feel good about having a place where people interact a lot.''
 She added: ''I don't know if I'm with the times, but I like that it's a slowed-down place in the middle of the city.''

 CORRECTION:
The Bensonhurst Journal article on Sunday, about opening weekend at the Nellie Bly Amusement Park in Brooklyn, gave an incorrect surname in some copies for the spokeswoman for an international amusement park association. She is Beth Robertson, not Roberston.

 As spring approaches at Nellie Bly, the water-target clown heads, the children's airplane ride and the horse race await the crowds of a new season. (Photographs by Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Refuge for City Children Faces Problems of Its Own

BYLINE: By MAREK FUCHS

 BODY:
The children of St. Basil, it would seem, cannot catch a break. 
 In January, the New York State Office of Children and Family Services declared that St. Basil Academy in Garrison, N.Y., a home for troubled children, would not receive the operating license it had applied for. Last week, the home received more bad news: the State Education Department ruled that its 22 children would no longer be eligible for a free education in the Garrison public schools they have attended since last fall. 
 It is tempting to see the story of St. Basil, which is run by the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, as one of children repeatedly cast out into the cold.
 But the reality is more complicated. While officials of the home have accused the school district of being racist and elitist -- most of the children are minority pupils from urban areas -- school officials say the issue is not race but residency: the children are not official residents of Garrison, and thus are not entitled to free education. The tiny district also contends that it cannot afford to teach them without charge.
 The controversy began last spring. St. Basil, in Putnam County, serves children who have been temporarily removed from abusive or dysfunctional homes, most of them referred by social service agencies. It used to educate them on its own 260-acre campus, but in 1997, it started sending them to elementary, middle and high schools in the neighboring Highland Falls-Fort Montgomery Central School District.
 In May, the district's Board of Education wrote to the Rev. Constantine Sitaras, the executive director of St. Basil, saying that the home owed the district $237,000 in back tuition and warning that the children could not continue at Highland Falls unless the money was paid or an agreement to pay it was reached. 
 In an interview in November, Father Sitaras said St. Basil decided over the summer of 2003 to send its children to Garrison public schools instead of to Highland Falls. He said that the academy had been having trouble raising money because of the economic ripples of Sept 11, but that its financial situation had nothing to do with the decision to change school districts. The schools, he contended, have a legal obligation to educate the children without charge because they are residents of Garrison. 
 Garrison disagreed. It noted that the children were in Garrison only as a result of temporary court orders, not permanent transfers of custody, and that their parents lived elsewhere. Many of the children are from New York City, and some are from other states. 
 Just days before the school year started, though, Richard P. Mills, the state commissioner of education, issued a temporary ruling that held the Garrison schools responsible for educating the children. 
 Garrison residents and officials complained bitterly about the strain the commissioner's decision was having on the district. Costs to hire more staff members and to absorb students with troubled backgrounds and learning and psychological issues were almost $400,000, more than 5 percent of the district's annual budget, said Dr. Ellen Bergman, the superintendent of the Garrison schools. 
 St. Basil called the concerns misplaced, the product of racism and an unhealthy focus on test scores all too inherent in wealthy areas.
 Then, late last year, St. Basil was found to be caring for children without a state license. Father Sitaras said last November that the home was not aware that it needed to apply for a different license when it stopped educating children in 1997. After learning it needed one, it promptly applied to the State Office of Children and Family Services, and in January was rejected for several reasons, including the fact that, on its application, it had not admitted owing money to the Highland Falls school district.
 The state has offered St. Basil the chance to appeal and allowed it to continue operating in the meantime, finding no fault with its care. 
 Last week, though, the education commissioner reconsidered his temporary order regarding the status of St. Basil students as Garrison residents. Mr. Mills ruled that they were, for purposes of public education, not Garrison residents. He pointed to the lack of official transfer of custody to St. Basil and the fact that students can eventually go back to their parents' homes. St. Basil cannot be considered a child care institution, a status that might have weighed in its favor, because it has no license. The responsibility for paying for the children's education rests with either the students' home districts or with St. Basil, Mr. Mills wrote.
 The students can stay the remainder of the year, he added, but the district can seek reimbursement. 
 Michael Lambert, a lawyer for St. Basil, said on Friday that there had been no discussion of legal appeals of the Education Department's decision. St. Basil's posture is that it is generally pleased with the ruling, despite its loss on the contention that the students had status as residents. He said the commissioner's decision that the home districts of the in-state students had to cover the cost of their education was, ''from St. Basil's perspective, a good thing.''
 But Superintendent Bergman, who said that the ruling on the residency issue was gratifying, pointed with unease to the commissioner's determination that St. Basil children who come from out of state must be the financial obligation of St. Basil. 
 Considering St. Basil's payment history, a contract is needed, Dr. Bergman said, adding, ''The Board of Education would be somewhat skeptical as to whether they would pay.''

HEADLINE: New Mood Around the Budget

BYLINE: By AVI SALZMAN

 BODY:
HERE is an obvious point: Gov. John G. Rowland has been weakened politically by investigations into gift-giving in his administration. Here is a less obvious one: Mr. Rowland's position may mean more poor people get health care, that schools in the state have more teachers, and that the rich pay for these programs. It could affect whether some mentally retarded people get help from the state and it could change the process of creating a budget itself.
 Democrats who had previously fought against Mr. Rowland in the budget process, and many times lost, expect to win concessions in this year's budget from a governor who has lost his political clout.
 Mr. Rowland, who has been busy rounding up thousands of documents requested by federal investigators and answering questions about ethics, may be forced to make deals he would not have accepted in the past. For some, it is a welcome change. 
 ''Some folks may have fallen off their high horses and realized they should be dealing down here on the ground with the rest of government and the rest of humanity,'' said Representative Andrew Fleischmann, a Democrat from West Hartford.
 Dean Pagani, the governor's chief of staff and spokesman, denied that the governor's position on budget matters had weakened. Because of the improving economy, the governor won't likely be under pressure to cut a deal this year, he said.
 ''Republicans in the House and Senate are still very much aligned with the governor on budget issues,'' Mr. Pagani said. ''The theory that Democrats are going to get something in the budget that they haven't gotten in the past is not very well thought out.''
 Some elected officials, along with advocates for social service agencies, said they were beginning to test the theory and had begun to prepare for life without this governor if the Senate convicts him. With that in mind, Health Care for All Coalition, a nonprofit agency that works to expand access to affordable health care, initiated the Jodi Rell Call-In Campaign last month, in which advocates called the lieutenant governor's office to persuade her to support changes in Medicaid funding.
 ''She's a high-ranking officer,'' said Gretchen Vivier, the director of the coalition, when asked why the group was focusing on Ms. Rell. Almost as an afterthought, she added, ''And there's also the possibility that she could be governor.''
 Representative James O'Rourke, a Democrat from Cromwell, said the impeachment investigation into the governor could end around the same time he is expected to sign the budget.
 ''It's a possibility the impeachment or resignation of the governor could happen right around the time that we would normally see the final budget be negotiated and come together,'' he said. ''So I was trying to think how that might work.
 ''If the guy's hanging on by a very slim thread,'' he said, ''he may not be a factor at all.''
 If the impeachment investigation does wind up just as the budget talks are ending, Mr. O'Rourke said many people won't know how to proceed. ''We don't know what's going to happen, when exactly everything's going to come together,'' he said. ''It's very uncertain and it's hard to tell.''
 That raises another important political question: Would Democrats rather negotiate with a hamstrung governor or with Ms. Rell, a steadfast fiscal conservative who has recently received strong support from lawmakers in both parties.
 As Jeff Miller, a Sandy Hook resident, wrote in a letter to The New Haven Advocate a few weeks ago, ''Why not use his moment of weakness to our state's advantage?''
 ''Why not put his shame to some good public use?'' he asked. ''Why not use his tenuous status to set the agenda for him instead of him dictating fiscal and social policy?''
 Stringing the governor along while his opponents remake the state budget is not an option, Democrats said. The impeachment process is unfolding independent of the budget process and could reach a conclusion before the governor gets a chance to vote on the budget.
 ''I don't think there's anyone who wants this cloud hanging over state government for any longer than it needs to,'' Mr. Fleischmann said.
 Unfortunately for the governor's opponents, the state's economy has only just begun to recover from its recessionary slump. Because the budget is rewritten every two years, this year's budget is considered an ''adjustment'' to last year's projections, and it doesn't give lawmakers much leeway to raise spending without also raising taxes. Lawmakers on both political sides considered last year's budget a disaster. The economy has improved over the past year and the state is expecting to receive more tax money, giving the Legislature a chance to amend some of the cuts made last year.
 But constraints on the budget continue to hamper efforts by Democrats to restore services slashed from last year's budget. The $14.3 billion spending package passed by the appropriations committee last month was a paltry $1.8 million under the state spending cap.
 Among the biggest priorities for the Democrats was reinstating funding for Medicaid and state-sponsored health programs. Medicaid recipients were unfairly saddled with premiums and co-pays that put health care out of reach for the state's poorest residents, Democrats said. That was among Democrats' biggest regrets from last year, and they said they plan to make it right.
 Cheri Quickmire, coordinator for One Connecticut, a coalition of more than 120 labor, social service and advocacy groups, said agencies that help poor people were pushing hard for these changes.
 ''That people who make $9,500 should pay $300 in premiums is just absurd,'' she said.
 Though Ms. Quickmire said she thought restoring the health care funds would ''fly on its own merits,'' she also realized the governor's position may offer an unusual opportunity. ''We are certainly hopeful that there will be leadership in the House and Senate,'' she said. ''It does seem like now would be a good time.''
 Marc Ryan, the governor's budget chief, said restoring health care spending is irresponsible and will be out of the state's reach in the long run.
 ''We can't afford these gold-plated types of health care plans for clients,'' Mr. Ryan said.
 The Democrats' plan would spend $41 million more than the governor on aid to municipalities, with some of that money going to magnet schools, according to the Office of Fiscal Analysis.
 Republicans on the appropriations committee, who voted overwhelmingly in March against the budget adjustments, said irresponsible spending in the past had put the state in an untenable position. A brightening economy isn't an excuse to repeat those mistakes, they said.
 ''We are paying dearly for our failure to be responsible over the last two years,'' said State Senator Robert Genuario, a Republican from Norwalk.
 Mr. Ryan has warned against increases in spending that could hurt the state's bond ratings and the health of the state's economy.
 Mr. Rowland isn't holding the line on all social service spending. He proposed increasing the budget for the Department of Mental Retardation to get people off that organization's waiting list for residential housing. The appropriations committee, however, voted to reduce the increase.
 Democrats and Republicans are also gearing up for a fight on the revenue side. The governor and the Democrat-controlled Legislature are fighting over whether to increase ''sin'' taxes on alcohol and cigarettes or raise taxes on the wealthiest people -- the so-called ''millionaire's tax.''
 The Democrat-controlled Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee passed a proposal about two weeks ago to impose higher taxes on joint filers who make more than $1 million, or $500,000 if they file separately, as well as increasing the state's inheritance tax.
 ''There is no way the governor is going to sign onto a budget that will reinstate the inheritance tax or increase the income tax,'' Mr. Ryan said.
 If the Democrats try to force the governor's hand on these budget adjustments, the governor may vote to stick with what the state passed last year, Mr. Ryan said.
 It may be harder for Democrats to gauge how far Mr. Rowland will bend on the budget this year, because he has been holding far fewer meetings with legislative leaders about the budget than he did in the past.
 ''I'm concerned the governor hasn't been as involved in discussions with top legislative leaders,'' said Representative Peter A. Metz, the ranking Republican on the Appropriations Committee.
 Though Mr. Metz said ''the governor has the ability to be just as effective as ever,'' he acknowledged that some Republicans do not share his confidence.
 ''I think people see the governor as working from a personal level,'' he said. ''He certainly has a strong personal influence. They're afraid that he'll lose that ability.''
 And now, some Democrats said, Mr. Ryan has appeared more willing to listen to ideas he dismissed in the past.
 Mr. Fleischmann said he was getting a better response this year to a performance-based budgeting proposal he said he thought could reform the budget process. The proposal would target government money to successful programs.
 ''It's very basic stuff that promotes good government,'' he said. ''For years when I brought up that topic I've run into a brick wall with this administration.''
 But during an Appropriations Committee hearing last month, Mr. Fleischmann said he noticed a change in the budget chief's position on the bill.
 ''He was far more open to the idea and accommodating and prepared to work with me and other legislators to make it happen than he has ever been since I met him,'' he said. ''This year I heard something much more open and accommodating. My political instincts tell me that in an environment where this administration has so many battles to be fighting and so many fires to be putting out, they're working to avoid unnecessary conflict.''
 Mr. Ryan said the governor's administration had not suddenly changed positions.
 ''I don't buy that because we've been pushing a number of accountability measures for years and the Legislature has shunned them,'' he said. He also said the governor had been as involved as ever in the budget process.
 ''He's always been actively involved in the budget and that hasn't changed one iota since some of these issues have arisen,'' Mr. Ryan said.
 Regardless of how much Mr. Rowland is involved in the day-to-day squabbles on the budget, both his opponents and supporters expect he will get to play the last hand. He, after all, can veto any budget.
 ''He still has that red pen,'' Ms. Vivier said.

HEADLINE: Billions of Trees Planted, and Nary a Dent in the Desert

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: AKSU, China 

 BODY:
Above a bumpy road on which each passing vehicle kicks up a cloud of dust, a red banner proclaims: ''Plant trees. Create forests. It's good for the nation.''
 Nearby, a farmer, Zhang Minqing, explained what he and his wife were doing scratching at what looked from a distance like bone-dry earth, but was really a tree farm in its infancy. The couple assured a visitor that the tiny sprigs would grow up to bear fruit in just five years, but the scene appeared all but hopeless. 
 ''Last year our first crop failed because we didn't know what we were doing,'' said Mr. Zhang, who migrated here from Sichuan Province, to take advantage of farm subsidies and promises of abundant land. ''We didn't provide enough water and they all died.''
 His sprigs of jujube trees are part of a 25-year effort by the Chinese government to rein in the Taklimakan, a desert as large as Germany. 
 International forestry experts say the scale of China's tree planting far surpasses anything ever tried. 
 According to government statistics, 42 billion trees have been planted since 1982. Last year alone, the effort involved more than 560 million people. In the latest phase of the effort, announced two years ago, China plans to plant trees in an area of 170,000 square miles -- just over the size of California -- over a decade.
 In Xinjiang, this western-most province, which is home to some of the world's biggest deserts, two million acres of trees have already been planted. It is all part of a plan to create more than a thousand ''green walls'' that will fence in the desert. Jujube trees are particularly suited to the harsh climate here, able to withstand winter temperatures near minus 30 degrees while thriving in the scorching summers.
 And yet for all their efforts, officials are hard pressed to answer two fundamental questions: has tree planting on this scale done any good, and what has it cost? 
 By one measure, the huge program appears to have achieved little. It is sandstorm season in China, a sky-darkening, lung-choking phenomenon involving wind-borne dust from the Taklimakan and Gobi deserts that plays havoc with aviation in northern China for weeks, cripples high-tech manufacturing and worsens respiratory problems as far downstream as Japan, the Korean peninsula and even the western United States.
 According to a recent report by the United Nations Environmental Program, the average number of sandstorms in China has grown from 5 in the 1960's to 24 in the 1990's. The Chinese Government itself reports that the country's deserts are expanding at a rate of 3,800 square miles a year. Indeed, some of the country's largest deserts appear to be merging.
 No exhaustive reckoning of the cost of the efforts to contain the desert, much less an appraisal of its cost effectiveness, has ever been carried out. Mass campaigns like these began in China's early Communist history, when huge social and natural engineering efforts were undertaken, often with disastrous effects.
 As part of a drive to give China the highest crop yields in the world in the mid-1950's, Mao Zedong began his so-called Four No's Campaign, putting millions of people to the task of trying to eliminate rats, sparrows, flies and mosquitoes. So many of the birds were killed that crops were infested with their natural prey, caterpillars.
 During a 1950's campaign to make China a leading steel producer, for example, part of the country's disastrous Great Leap Forward, the countryside was stripped of trees for fuel to fire backyard furnaces, causing widespread floods.
 No one expects that today's tree planting efforts will have anything like these calamitous side effects, but if the campaign is not effective, the huge cost is, if nothing else, a financial disaster. 
 Jiang Gaoming, an expert with the Chinese Academy of Science, said the government would do better to ''leave the desert alone.''
 To plant trees on such a vast scale, ''economically and ecologically, it is a big waste of money,'' he said. ''There is a serious problem of interests involved, and some people don't care, because it is state money.'' 
 Liu Tuo, director of the state Antidesertification Office, rejected criticism of the program's merits. ''This is a comprehensive effort to fight the desertification problem, and it is the correct policy,'' he said. ''The reason the desert was still growing at the end of the 20th century is not because the policy is wrong. It results from the pressure of population growth and the resulting damage to the environment.'' 
 Many international experts, however, say that at best the jury is still out. ''There are all kinds of Johnny Appleseed-type stories about some guy who keeps planting trees in the desert, and 50 years later, the land is back,'' said William Hyde, an economist and forester with extensive experience in China. ''I just don't know if this works, and if it does, what the cost- benefit basis of it is. And I don't think any Chinese agricultural economist has looked seriously into this either.''
 Stands of poplars line the roads out of town and rise here and there from otherwise desolate-looking earth.
 ''Everyone in the project must work 26 days a year planting trees, and if you work more, you get paid extra,'' said Liu Xuemin, a 33-year-old farmer who leaned against his mud-caked Forever bicycle next to an irrigated field full of saplings. ''The idea is to plant these trees here as a break against the sand, which is carried by the wind.''
 Asked if there was real desert nearby, Mr. Liu issued a sharp chuckle, and pointed to a nearby path strewn with tumbleweed and brambles, saying, ''Just follow that.'' At the end of the path, just beyond a tall berm, Sahara-like dunes stretched to the horizon.

HEADLINE: Zestfully Pursuing A Living, In the Raw

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS. 
E-mail: amh@nytimes.com

 BODY:
''EXPERIENCED Shucker Wanted,'' the sign in the window said. ''Inquire Within.''
 As signs go, this one has captured its share of attention in the three weeks since it went up at Jezebel, one of the few longtime, black-owned, upscale restaurants in New York, let alone Midtown. People have peered at it, asked about it, and a couple of people have even applied. But then attention seems to come effortlessly for Alberta Wright, proprietor of Jezebel, a former lover's pet name for Ms. Wright, who was sitting this day on a barstool wearing mannish loafers, flouncy black skirt and silver bangle earrings. 
 In this case, it was that oxymoronic juxtaposition of the phrase ''shucker wanted,'' which seemed to be advertising a working-class position dockside in a rough part of town, and the antique gentility of the admonition ''Inquire Within'' that caught the eye.
 But Ms. Wright is like that too, oxymoronic. She can talk about friends like Michael Douglas, Andre Leon Talley, Lauren Hutton as if everybody had them, saying that they helped her when she started out, and in the next breath let slip that she was a migrant laborer, so many years ago that she doesn't care to count them. 
 She never craved a raw bar, until now. ''One man came by and said: 'Shucker! What kind of shucker are you looking for?''' she recounted.
 Her son, Michael, an actor (''The Principal,'' with James Belushi, ''Sugar Hill,'' with Wesley Snipes), happened to be in the restaurant at the time. ''Oyster shucker,'' he said. ''Raw bar.''
 The man was not mollified. He warned Mr. Wright: ''Some black guy is going to come by from the ghetto, and say: 'Let's shuck. What you want me to shuck? Take it all off.'''
 This drove Ms. Wright to the Internet, where she looked up ''shuck'' in the Merriam-Webster Dictionary, and discovered that it did, indeed, have to do with removing outer coverings. So she amended her sign to read, ''Experienced Oyster Shucker Wanted. Inquire Within.''
 A couple of men who said they had been oyster shuckers at Docks on the Upper West Side applied, but the one she liked never returned. ''Let me tell you, there aren't many shuckers,'' she said. ''You can't leave sand or shell in the oyster, because people can choke on that. You have to know how to smell 'em, make sure the oysters are good.''
 She considered luring a shucker from another raw bar, but worried about the ethics of such a move. She regretted not having visited the picket line outside the Oyster Bar at Grand Central Terminal before the strike there was settled two weeks ago. ''I know a lot of these guys are Mexican, and people have a tendency not to pay them well. I was a migrant worker one time, so I know.''
 Ms. Wright grew up on a farm outside Charleston, S.C., the youngest of nine children. At 17, she hitched a ride to Florida on a trailer truck. ''I picked string beans,'' she said. ''I packed celery. I cut lettuce. Trust me, I'm the type to do anything to make a living.''
 As ''Summertime'' blared over the sound system, Ms. Wright jumped off her bar stool. ''Hey, guys, that's too loud,'' she demurred. Not that she didn't like the singer. ''Aaron Neville. Him and Ron Isley, they're my two favorites.'' 
 The dinner hour was heating up, and Ms. Wright excused herself for a moment to seat a customer. ''Hirschman,'' said the customer, an older woman in heavy silver beads. Behind her was her husband, Albert O. Hirschman, the economist whom some credit with popularizing the concept of the exit strategy, which he called the exit option, and who was celebrating his 89th birthday. ''As long as you're in love, you can sit close,'' Ms. Wright cooed, finding a corner table where Warhol's Muhammad Ali looked down from one side and a gauzy French maiden from the other. 
 Ms. Wright recommended the she-crab soup, spiked with sherry and nutmeg. She doesn't like to overindulge in her own she-crab soup; so much cream. Ms. Wright is very thin.
 And stylish. She has sold antique clothing and antique furniture. She ran a restaurant, also named Jezebel, on the Left Bank in Paris. She opened it on impulse --she had had a French boyfriend, a grandnephew of Toulouse-Lautrec -- and closed it after a few years. The New York Jezebel has lasted 20.
 How does one get from South Carolina to Paris and New York? ''I have no idea,'' she replied. ''Life, you know, we gotta take it all in stride.'' 
 Then Ms. Wright changed the subject to more urgent matters. ''This shucker thing. I really hope I get a shucker, let me tell you. Clams, scallops. I make a salad out of raw scallop with balsamic vinegar. My own recipe.''
 Inquire within.
