HEADLINE: Below the Campaign Radar, a Values War

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16 

 BODY:
On the campaign trail, President Bush rarely mentions his support for a constitutional amendment banning gay marriage. John Kerry is talking far more about his economic plan than about abortion rights.
 But advocacy groups on the left and the right are mobilizing furiously around those hot-button social issues. They are convinced that the country is at a turning point on them, and that the consensus of the next election -- no matter how narrow -- could be locked in for a generation, because of the number of judges the next president will appoint.
 ''What happens over the next seven months will determine what the law of the land is for the next 20 years,'' said Ralph Neas, the president of the liberal advocacy group People for the American Way. 
 Deal W. Hudson, the conservative publisher of the Roman Catholic magazine Crisis and an occasional White House adviser, said, ''I don't think the contrast could be greater between the two candidates.''
 For the activists, the goal is not just to energize their fellow liberals or conservatives -- although that will be crucial in this election year -- but also to single out sympathetic swing voters in important states, like Republican women who support abortion rights, or Catholics drawn to Democratic economic policies but Republican cultural positions.
 To that end, the advocacy groups are trying to define the opposition candidate as extreme, ''outside the mainstream.''
 The National Right to Life Committee recently denounced Senator Kerry in its newspaper for what it called his commitment to ''unlimited abortion on demand.'' Mr. Hudson said conservative Catholics were urging American bishops to deny communion to Mr. Kerry, a Catholic, whom he described as ''not just a liberal but a liberal's liberal'' and an ''enthusiast'' of abortion.
 On the other side, the major abortion rights groups are planning a ''March for Women's Lives'' in Washington on April 25 to protest what its organizers call an ''anti-choice White House.'' Kate Michelman, president of Naral Pro-Choice America, said her movement was determined not to let Mr. Bush avoid the issue, arguing that ''he wants to take the right to choose away from American women.''
 Similar organizing is under way among gay rights and social conservative groups on gay marriage.
 There are stark differences between the candidates on these issues. Mr. Bush, for example, supports a constitutional amendment to outlaw same-sex marriage, and recently asserted in a speech that an amendment is the only way to protect the institution of marriage from ''activist courts and local officials'' who want to redefine it. Mr. Kerry says such an amendment is wrong; he opposes gay marriage but supports civil unions, and he has accused Mr. Bush of practicing divisive politics on the issue.
 Mr. Bush is on record as a longtime opponent of legalized abortion, except in cases of rape and incest and to save a woman's life. Last fall he signed into law the first federal ban on a specific abortion procedure, the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act of 2003, and he has appointed some prominent opponents of a constitutional right to abortion to federal appeals courts. He has said the country is not ready for an outright ban on abortion, although his party's platform calls for one, and he often speaks of working to ''build a culture of life.''
 Mr. Kerry has a 100 percent rating from Naral Pro-Choice America and has promised to block any nominee to the Supreme Court who does not support Roe v. Wade, the 1973 decision that recognized a right to abortion. He was one of 34 senators who voted against the Partial Birth Abortion Ban Act, on the ground that that it had no exception for the use of the procedure to protect the health of the pregnant woman.
 Another sharp distinction is on the issue of capital punishment. Mr. Kerry, a former prosecutor, has long opposed the death penalty, although he now supports its use against terrorists and has said he would respect state laws that call for it. Mr. Bush was governor of a state that led the nation in executions.
 The campaigns themselves, so far, are not hammering those differences as hard as they might, at least with general audiences. This is not surprising, some analysts say. ''When you're running nationwide with so many different constituencies, it's hard to take on these issues without wondering whether you're going to drive away as many as you attract,'' said Andrew Kohut, director of the Pew Research Center.
 History suggests both the effectiveness and the risks. The 1988 campaign of the first President George Bush devastated the Democratic nominee, Michael S. Dukakis, by defining him as soft on crime and excessively devoted to civil liberties. Four years later, though, Republican appeals to ''family values'' and the declaration of a cultural war at the party's convention were widely thought to have backfired. The younger Mr. Bush campaigned carefully on social issues in 2000.
 These days, Bush campaign officials say the social issues may not be front and center, like terrorism and the economy, but will be dealt with. Terry Holt, a campaign spokesman, asserted that ''there will be a discussion about who is more in the mainstream.''
 The Republican National Committee this week issued a scathing critique of Mr. Kerry's voting record, in advance of a meeting of Southern Republicans. Ed Gillespie, the national party chairman, declared in the critique that Mr. Kerry's ''out-of-the-mainstream positions put him at odds with millions of voters who care about lower taxes, respect for a culture of life, preserving the institution of marriage and providing the funding necessary to enable our troops to do their jobs.''
 Michael Meehan, a spokesman for the Kerry campaign, said he expected the Republicans to use social issues on a very focused state-by-state basis. ''They're not going to have this conversation where suburban women can hear it,'' Mr. Meehan said.
 Even so, Mr. Kerry's allies say he will not sit idly by and allow the Republicans to define him as an outside-the-mainstream social liberal, as they did with Mr. Dukakis. They say he is not afraid to defend his values, and they argue that he did so effectively in his 1996 re-election campaign in Massachusetts against Gov. William F. Weld.
 Still, Rob Gray, a Republican political consultant in Boston who worked for Mr. Weld in 1996, said that handling such issues in Massachusetts, a heavily Democratic and relatively liberal state, was quite different from handling them in a national campaign. Mr. Gray added that while Mr. Kerry was ''a good debater and a good campaigner,'' he had been ''spoiled in Massachusetts.''
 For now, the debate over social issues is largely being waged by the advocacy groups. Activists on both the left and the right fear that the next president will be elected without voters ever realizing the stakes, particularly given the likely turnover in the Supreme Court. The next president could end up appointing two or more justices to the court, where there has not been a death or retirement since 1994.
 Ms. Michelman of Naral Pro-Choice America said she hoped that the April 25 march would put abortion rights ''at the forefront of the political debate at a very important time.'' Tony Perkins, president of the Family Research Council, a social conservative organization, said he hoped to see much more emphasis on the gay marriage issue in the Bush campaign.
 One way or the other, the battle over social issues will be joined.

HEADLINE: Is It Grade Inflation, or Are Students Just Smarter?

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON

 BODY:
A MILLION dollars isn't what it used to be, and neither is an A in college.
 A's -- including A-pluses and A-minuses -- make up about half the grades at many elite schools, according to a recent survey by Princeton of the Ivy League and several other leading universities.
 At Princeton, where A's accounted for 47 percent of grades last year, up from 31 percent in the 1970's, administrators and some faculty have proposed correcting for so-called grade inflation by limiting A's to 35 percent of course grades. 
 Not everyone is convinced there is a problem. A recent study by Clifford Adelman of the United States Department of Education concluded that there were only minor changes in grade distributions between the 1970's and the 1990's, even at highly selective institutions. (A bigger change, he said, was the rise in the number of students withdrawing from courses and repeating courses for higher grades.) 
 Alfie Kohn, author of the coming book ''More Essays on Standards, Grading and Other Follies'' (Beacon Press), says rising grades ''don't in itself prove that grade inflation exists.''
 ''It's necessary to show -- and, to the best of my knowledge, it has never been shown -- that those higher grades are undeserved,'' he said. 
 Is it possible that the A students deserve their A's?
 Getting into colleges like Princeton is far more difficult than it used to be. And increasing numbers of students are being bred like racehorses to breeze through standardized tests and to write essays combining Albert Einstein's brilliance with Mother Teresa's compassion.
 Partly to impress admissions officers, students are loading up on Advanced Placement courses. The College Board said the number taking 10 or more such courses in high school is more than 10 times what it was a decade ago. And classes aimed at helping them do better on the SAT exams are booming.
 ''Back in 1977, when I graduated from high school, it had to be less than 25,000 students nationally who spent more than $100 on preparing for the SAT,'' said John Katzman, founder and chief executive of The Princeton Review, which tutors about 60,000 students a year for the SAT's. ''It was the C students who prepped, not the A students,'' he added. ''Now it's got to be circa 200,000 or 250,000 students who are going to spend more than $400 to prepare for the SAT.''
 But Wayne Camara, vice president of research at the College Board, said that while students are increasingly well prepared, ''that in no way accounts for the shift in grades we are seeing.''
 ''Grades are not like temperatures or weights,'' he said. ''What constitutes an A or a B has changed, both in high school and in college.''
 He said teachers are aware of how competitive the academic world has become and try to help students by giving better grades. ''If you graduated from college in the 1950's and you wanted to go to law school or a graduate program, you could,'' Dr. Camara said. ''Today it is very difficult. You are not going to be able to graduate from Harvard or Princeton with a 2.8 grade point average and get into Georgetown Law.''
 In addition, one recent Princeton graduate who works in investment banking and has participated in recruiting meetings cautioned in a letter to The Daily Princetonian that hiring practices can be superficial, and that grade-point averages are one of the first items scrutinized on a resume.
 Stuart Rojstaczer, a geology professor at Duke who runs the Web site www.Gradeinflation.com, says that higher grades are the result of a culture where the student-consumer is king. ''We don't want to offend students or parents,'' he said. ''They are customers and the customer is always right.''
 Valen E. Johnson, a biostatistics professor at the University of Michigan and author of ''Grade Inflation: A Crisis in College Education'' (Springer Verlag), said the use of student ratings to evaluate teachers also inflates grades: ''As long as our evaluations depend on their opinion of us, their grades are going to be high.'' 
 Even if the Princeton plan is approved, Professor Johnson, who unsuccessfully tried to lower grades at Duke University a few years ago, cautioned that reform is difficult. ''It is not in the interest of the majority to reform the system,'' he said. ''Assigning grades, particularly low grades, is tough, and it requires more work, since low grades have to be backed up with evidence of poor performance.''
 But Princeton and others may take some comfort from Reed College, a selective liberal arts college in Oregon, where the average grade-point average has remained a sobering 2.9 (on a 4.0 scale) for 19 years. 
 The college says it ranks third among all colleges and universities in the proportion of students who go on for Ph.D.s, and has produced more than 50 Fulbright Scholars and 31 Rhodes scholars.
 Still, Colin S. Diver, Reed's president, says graduate schools worried about their rankings are becoming less willing to take students with lower grades because they make the graduate schools appear less selective.
 ''If they admit someone with a 3.0 from Reed who is in the upper half of the class, that counts against them, even if it is a terrific student,'' Mr. Diver said. ''I keep saying to my colleagues here that we can hold ourselves out of the market for only so long.''


CORRECTION-DATE: April 25, 2004

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about grade inflation gave an incomplete title for a book by Alfie Kohn, who said, ''Even if grades have gone up at Princeton, that doesn't in itself prove that grade inflation exists.'' His coming book is ''What Does It Mean to Be Well-Educated? And More Essays on Standards, Grading and Other Follies.''

HEADLINE: Looking for a Villain, and Finding One in China

BYLINE: By EDUARDO PORTER

 BODY:
REMEMBER when China was exporting deflation? It was only a couple of years ago when economists warned that the country's cheap manufactured exports could push the world dangerously close to a spiral of ever-lower prices. 
 ''The Chinese economy has certainly emerged as an important ingredient in the U.S. deflation story,'' warned Stephen S. Roach, chief economist of Morgan Stanley in October 2002. The World Bank also chimed in: ''China's overreliance on the external sector 'exports' China's own deflation to the rest of the world.''
 Well, that's over. In March, inflation reared its head in the United States. The Labor Department reported that in the first quarter of the year, consumer prices rose at an annual pace of 5.1 percent. But despite this U-turn in the outlook for prices, one thing didn't change: China is still part of the problem. 
 Carl B. Weinberg, chief economist of High Frequency Economics, wrote to investors last week that ''China's crowding into world commodity markets will boost perceived inflation in all the world's economies for a long time unless its growth trajectory is crimped.'' As an uncertain recovery in the job market and a bloated trade deficit stoke a lingering economic malaise in the United States, the prospect of China emerging as a competitor on an equal footing has led economists, businessmen and politicians to blame it for every economic woe.
 Almost every politician, it seems, agonizes over China's vast labor force sucking in the world's industrial jobs. A few fret about China becoming too large a consumer market, enabling it to dictate terms to American businessmen and policy makers. 
 Some concerns are warranted. China's fast growth has been the major force behind the surge in commodity prices. Last year it ate up half the world's concrete output, a quarter of its steel production, a fifth of its copper and about 40 percent of its coal. 
 Moreover, China's entry into several markets, from toys to T-shirts, pretty much wiped out the other producers. ''There are bound to be uneven effects in sectors they buy from and sectors that compete with them,'' said Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University. 
 But to hear some economists, it would seem that China has locked United States businesses in a deadly kung-fu grip. In a recent paper, John H. Makin of the American Enterprise Institute said China is choking off the profits of American companies with its hunger for commodities pushing up the price of raw materials and its cheap labor holding down the price of finished goods. 
 Even as China soaks up the world's manufacturing jobs, Mr. Makin wrote, Chinese workers are not spending their paychecks, salting them away instead in savings accounts and thus creating an imbalance between booming supply and weak demand.
 Congress has tried to come to the rescue. In February, a bipartisan group of senators argued that China's undervalued currency has played a ''major role'' in the loss of 2.6 million American manufacturing jobs, and submitted a bill to slap a punitive tariff on Chinese imports. 
 But many economists, including Mr. Bhagwati, argue that China is getting a bum rap. ''China's net effect on us is much less than what we think,'' Mr. Bhagwati said.
 For instance, critics in the United States point to last year's $124 billion trade deficit with China as proof that the country is destabilizing the global economy by adding too much demand and too little supply. But China's global trade surplus last year reached only $16 billion-- a better balance of supply and demand than the United States' $517 billion global deficit. 
 Besides, ''much of our bilateral deficit with China is the transfer of previous deficits with Korea and Taiwan,'' said Clyde V. Prestowitz, a trade adviser in the Reagan administration who heads the Economic Strategy Institute. ''Most of what China sends to us we stopped making back in the 1970's and 1980's.'' 
 Other economists argue that China's impact on prices is also overstated. In a recent study, economists at the Federal Reserve tried to figure out whether China was in fact exporting inflation or deflation to its trading partners. They concluded it was too small to do that. China accounts for only 5 percent of global exports and global gross domestic product, the study noted, and ''the impact of Chinese exports on global prices has been, while non-negligible, fairly modest.'' 
 Fears of an Asian menace have come and gone before. The recession in the early 90's prompted dread that Japan would become the world's pre-eminent economic power, opening a Japan-bashing season that featured Americans smashing Toyotas with sledgehammers. 
 What seems to trouble Americans most about China is not its current economic impact, but what it might become. According to Goldman Sachs, China's economy will be bigger than America's by 2041. ''It has the potential to displace the U.S.A. as the numero uno,'' said Mr. Prestowitz of the Economic Strategy Institute. ''That's the bottom line.''
 Mr. Weinberg at High Frequency says that Americans will stop worrying about the current Asian menace when they feel better about their own economy. ''If we were creating 200,000 jobs a month no one would care about China,'' he said. 
 The United States might then choose to see China as an upbeat influence: the supplier of cheap manufactured products that helps keep American consumer prices low; a key export market; and a major underwriter of the United States' budget deficit, which plows its savings into Treasury bills, contributing to America's economic recovery by helping keep interest rates low. 
 With fears of deflation dissipating, Mr. Roach at Morgan Stanley has taken to a more upbeat view of China's influence on the world: ''We ought to be thanking the Chinese,'' he wrote last month.
 But Americans probably won't.

HEADLINE: Yonder in Farmingdale, the Wild Blue

BYLINE: By MARCELLE S. FISCHLER. 
E-mail: lijournal@nytimes.com

 BODY:
TO start her flying lesson, Lindsay Arnott did a preflight check. Scanning gauges, altimeters and air-speed indicators, she flipped switches and ticked off a list of checks and rechecks with Steve Campbell, her instructor. Then Ms. Arnott revved up the engines, started the fuel pumps on the twin-engine Piper Seminole and taxied to the runway at Republic Airport in Farmingdale. Pushing the throttle forward, she pulled back on the stick and took off on wobbly wings to practice figure eights at 1,600 feet in the skies over Long Island. 
 Ms. Arnott, 23, is a professional pilot-aeronautical science major working on a bachelor's degree at Farmingdale State University. Besides her academic classes, she flies three times a week. As an undergraduate, she has accrued about 325 flight hours, earned a private pilot's license and instrument flying rating and is working on her commercial ticket. By the time she graduates in May, Ms. Arnott plans to be certified as a flight instructor, at which point she is guaranteed work at Farmingdale State University's flight school. A job at the school after graduation is a recently implemented perk, said Capt. Edward Tanza, director of training operations at the aviation center. Of the 20 certified flight instructors at Farmingdale, 6 are graduates of the program. 
 But Ms. Arnott has larger ambitions. Once she has 1,500 flying hours, she hopes to land a job as a commercial pilot, perhaps with a regional airline. ''I want to fly the big jets,'' she said. ''I want to travel the world.'' Until recently, the aviation program at Farmingdale State, founded in 1948, emphasized maintenance, aviation administration and avionics, not flying. But with the delivery of a $2.7 million fleet of 13 new single- and twin-engine Piper aircraft last fall, a revamping of the flight program and recent changes in top personnel, Farmingdale has zipped to the top tier of pilot programs in the Northeast. 
 ''It's one of the great untold stories of public aviation,'' said Lou Howard, a State University of New York trustee and former state assemblyman who got Farmingdale's course off the ground with three planes in 1969. It was a two-year program then. 
 Mr. Tanza, a retired airline captain, has flown DC-8's, DC-10's and 727's all over the globe. When Mr. Tanza, 59, took over Farmingdale's aviation center a year and a half ago, he set up a schedule for students that mimicked commercial airlines. 
 ''When they leave here, they have already been exposed to that type,'' Mr. Tanza said. ''Other schools really don't prepare them for the next step.'' Flying out of the fourth-busiest airport in the state, they also experience a complex airspace system, he said. 
 Additionally, pilots-in-training are required to have 35 hours of ground school, one-on-one with the instructor, to meet the rating, Mr. Tanza said. As part of a standardized program with an extensive syllabus, they spend hours in simulators familiarizing themselves with the instrumentation and take courses in aviation history, aviation law, advanced avionics and cockpit automation as well as English, economics and meteorology. 
 When Mr. Campbell arrived at Farmingdale seven years ago, he was the only flight instructor. The school, which opened its aviation education center and flight facility, with hangar, classrooms and a simulator laboratory at Republic in 1995, had no mechanic and a high student attrition rate. Students flew a handful of aging single-engine Cessnas and slow-flying, poorly equipped Diamond Katanas that were limited to being flown in good weather under visual flight rules.
 ''Within the last two years, it's really changed dramatically,'' Mr. Campbell said. Jonathan C. Gibralter, Farmingdale's president, said the aviation school's only competition on the Island was Dowling College, a private school in Oakdale. 
 ''They can't touch us on tuition,'' Dr. Gibralter said. 
 Tuition at Farmingdale runs $4,350 a year plus an additional $6,000 flight fee a semester, from which hourly flying fees are deducted. Fifteen of the 100 students in the professional pilot program are expected to graduate from the program in May; another 100 students are enrolled in an aviation administration program. Next fall, 150 students will be flying, a record number. 
 Dan Ciccone, 22, of Dix Hills, a senior, opted for Farmingdale because of the lower state tuition and the up-and-coming program. 
 ''They built it up from when I came here,'' said Mr. Ciccone, who coordinates flights as a dispatcher at the school as part of an extensive work-study program. ''It's a completely different program than it was originally. You've got the new planes, new scheduling policies, everything fits. Our aircraft are better than anyone else's aircraft around.''

'Honoring Her Honor'
 When the Suffolk County League of Women Voters decided to hold an ''Honoring Her Honor'' luncheon for female judges recently, the tally from the bench was 31. 
 ''We were staggered by the statistics,'' said Jacqui Lofaro, president of the league. 
 In the 30 years since Anne F. Mead was appointed district court judge, the first woman to be appointed or elected to a court of record in Suffolk, the number of female judges has increased 3,000 percent. 
 ''Still only around 28 percent of all judges in the county, it represents lasting change,'' Ms. Lofaro said.
 Judge Mead, 79 and now retired, joined 200 guests at a buffet at Villa Lombardi in Holbrook. Judge Mead said that when she graduated from law school in 1961, there were only five female lawyers in Suffolk. Finding a job was difficult. 
 ''People were not used to going to a woman lawyer,'' she recalled. After going to nearly every law firm in Suffolk, she landed a job doing title closings. Later, she was appointed to the Public Service Commission and started her own practice before becoming a judge.
 Judge Mead said she considered herself a trailblazer in the judiciary. 
 ''They weren't used to a woman on the bench at all,'' she said, though women served as justices of the peace on the East End. ''At first, the male attorneys weren't too happy with it, but as time wore on it worked out fine.''
 When Marion T. McNulty, an acting Supreme Court justice and supervising judge of the matrimonial part in Suffolk, came onto the bench in 1988, she was the first woman elected to countywide judicial office. 
 ''Suffolk was nearly 300 years old at that point in time,'' Justice McNulty said. ''It was a long time coming in this county.''
 What was once a challenge, she said, is now an accepted fact. 
 ''Attorneys accept women judges,'' she said. ''Other judges accept women judges. The political parties accept women as judicial candidates. I think that we have made our mark.''
 One of the newest town justices, Lisa Rana, started work at the East Hampton Town Justice Court in January. She seemed surprised by all the fuss. Judge Rana said integrity, discipline and personality were the important qualifications. ''Now there are more women judges because people are seeing it as less of a gender issue,'' she said. 
 Justice Gail Prudenti, who grew up in Blue Point, said that when she graduated from law school in 1978, she didn't think judicial opportunities were available for women. 
 That has clearly changed. Justice Prudenti, 51, started her judicial career in 1991 when she was elected to the State Supreme Court. In 2002, she became the first woman from Suffolk to serve as associate justice. Now she is presiding justice of the Appellate Division for the Second Judicial Department. 
 Statewide, Justice Prudenti said, the number of female judges has increased to 27 percent from 11 percent and on the appellate level to 21 percent from 2 percent. 
 ''By diversifying the judiciary with the inclusion of women, a brand of justice is delivered which is more representative of the values and principles held dear in our society as a whole,'' Justice Prudenti said in her keynote address. But she didn't criticize the pre-female judiciary.
 ''The woman judges in this room would not be here if it were not for the support of visionary men,'' Justice Prudenti said.

HEADLINE: U.N. Is Wary of Dangers In Taking Lead Role in Iraq

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE; John F. Burns contributed reporting from Baghdad, Iraq, for this article.

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 17 

 BODY:
The United Nations, once snubbed and excluded from the task of shaping Iraq's future, suddenly finds itself pressed to play the major role in that effort, but it is taking up the task with some foreboding.
 ''There is a mixture of vindication on the one hand and great apprehension on the other,'' said Edward Mortimer, a senior aide to Secretary General Kofi Annan. 
 Mr. Mortimer contrasted the recent calls for assistance from President Bush with the disparagement he said the United Nations had become used to from the administration. ''It's quite nice when you've been generally dissed about your irrelevancy and then suddenly have people coming on bended knee and saying, 'We need you to come back,' '' he said. ''On the other hand, it's quite unnerving to feel you're being projected into a very violent and volatile situation where you might be regarded as an agent or faithful servant of a power that has incurred great hostility.'' 
 With time running out on the June 30 deadline for transfer of power, the United Nations is being looked to as the only institution that can confer immediate global legitimacy on the American goal of bringing representative government to Iraq.
 But the challenges are formidable. United Nations officials are wary of being seen as a replacement occupying power in Iraq and will need to work with the United States while keeping an appropriate public distance from it.
 They are conscious of lingering resentment in Iraq from the days when the United Nations oversaw economic sanctions that caused great hardship. They are fearful of taking on ill-defined responsibility and being blamed for any subsequent failure. And they face mounting criticism at home over the scandal-ridden United Nations oil-for-food program that investigators say enabled Saddam Hussein to pocket more than $10 billion.
 In addition, Mr. Annan's aides say that he is resolved that any United Nations staff members who return to Baghdad have proper protection. He told members of the Security Council this week that he would delay sending people back in force until he had that assurance.
 The last United Nations mission to Iraq pulled out in October, after the bombing of its headquarters on Aug. 19 that killed 22 people, including the mission chief, Sergio Vieira de Mello.
 ''We have an obligation since last summer to insist on clarity and on what is being asked of us,'' Mr. Mortimer said. ''What are the risks? What kind of guarantees can you give us that we are not going to be blown up? And is the job important enough to justify the risk?''
 Nancy Soderberg, vice president of the International Crisis Group and a former senior American diplomat at the United Nations, said: ''In my time at the U.N., I have never seen such a strong determination to stand up to the pressure to go into a situation that's not right in their minds. They're digging in their heels to get something that is, in Kofi's words, realistic, feasible and advisable.''
 Mr. Annan indicated that the United Nations would do its post-transition consulting on elections and the creation of a permanent constitution for Iraq with small teams, and that the organization would not return in force to Iraq ''for the foreseeable future.'' Aides say that probably means only after elections have been held in January 2005, the date that his envoy, Lakhdar Brahimi, said on Wednesday would produce a ''genuinely representative government.''
 Mr. Brahimi is due back in New York at the end of the week to brief the Security Council on his recommendations for a caretaker government to be put in place by the June 30 transfer of sovereignty back to Iraq.
 After 11 days of consultation in Iraq, he made preliminary proposals for an interim administration led by a prime minister, a president and two vice presidents to be chosen by him, a group of Iraqi judges and members of the Iraqi Governing Council and the United States-led occupying force. He also proposed the dissolution of the American-appointed council and a post-transition gathering of leaders to choose a consultative assembly to advise the interim government.
 It is not yet clear how powerful Iraqis have received Mr. Brahimi's proposals. Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the Shiite leader whose opposition effectively forced the United States to abandon its earlier proposals for the turnover of power, has remained silent about the matter.
 Mr. Bush praised Mr. Brahimi in a White House news conference on Tuesday.
 A Security Council ambassador from a country that had opposed the war a year ago emphasized that this year there would be no dissension. ''It will be a mood of cooperation,'' he said. ''If the Americans and the British come up with a way to really make the transfer of sovereignty a transfer of real responsibility, things will be quite positive.''
 The new Security Council resolution will outline the United Nations role in the post-transition phase, authorize a United States-led multinational force to help stabilize the country leading up to the elections, and define the relationship between the new Iraqi interim authorities, the United Nations and the United States-led military force.
 The United States ambassador to the United Nations, John D. Negroponte, who is expected to become ambassador in Baghdad in July, said Friday that talk of what the resolution might say was in a very preliminary stage. 
 ''We really haven't gotten into this, there's no specific draft on the table,'' he told reporters. ''There's some thinking that's being done both in our government and in others, but I don't expect anything to surface in the very near future.''
 Mr. Negroponte appealed for nations to send troops for a force dedicated specifically to the protection of the United Nations, but there appeared to be no takers. President Jacques Chirac of France said in a news conference in Algiers that under the current circumstances the proposal was ''totally out of the question.''
 The prospect of the return of the United Nations to Iraq as a powerful arbitrator of the country's future arouses mixed feelings among ordinary Iraqis. Perhaps more than any other people in the Arab world, the Iraqis came to know the United Nations at close quarters during the years when economic sanctions were applied against Saddam Hussein's government. 
 United Nations agencies became responsible for the oil-for-food program, which provided rations that sustained more than 70 percent of the population. Although the program was badly corrupted, many Iraqis remain grateful for what they regard as the impartial and humane behavior of United Nations officials throughout those years.
 When the United Nations compound in Baghdad was bombed last August, there was widespread grief and even a sense of shame among Iraqis that the organization could be subjected to such violence. 
 But there is also a widespread feeling that the United Nations, lacking any powers other than persuasion, may not be resolute enough to withstand the sort of pressures it is likely to endure during a period of potential tumult in Iraqi politics. 
 When Mr. Brahimi spoke on Iraqi television this week outlining his proposals for reworking the American plan to carry Iraq to sovereignty this summer and to elections, some Iraqis watched with concern. ''It sounds good,'' an Iraqi engineer said. ''But how strong is Brahimi? How strong is the U.N.?''

HEADLINE: This Ship Is So Big, The Verrazano Cringes

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
A Queen does not have to live by everyday rules, especially not a Queen whose, um, measurements exceed those of famous ancestors.
 The Queen in question here is the new Queen Mary 2, the 1,132-foot-long Cunarder whose maiden voyage to New York this week has steamship buffs longing for the days when crossing the Atlantic took days, not hours, and when the ships were as stylish as the passengers. Dowdy freighters and impersonal container ships the grand old ocean liners were not. 
 ''This is like the second coming for steamship buffs,'' said William Miller, the author of 60 books on ships and the adjunct curator of the ocean liner collection at the South Street Seaport Museum. ''It's almost mind-boggling, a liner of this size arriving in New York.'' 
 The Queen Mary 2 is the longest, tallest, widest and heaviest nonmilitary vessel in history. That includes the ship's famous relatives, the original Queen Mary (now a hotel by the docks in Long Beach, Calif.) and the Queen Elizabeth 2.
 The Queen Mary 2 is also the most expensive ship in the world, both to build and to board. It cost $800 million, and accommodations range from $1,869 for a cabin to $27,499 for what the Cunard Line calls a ''grand duplex.''
 As if all those superlatives were not enough, Mr. Miller added more: the most celebrated ship of its time, the most publicized ship of its time, the most anxiously awaited ship of its time. ''I was getting tired last year, hearing another rivet had been put in the hull or some such, but everybody was on the edge of their seat,'' he said.
 Being the longest ship in the world -- 86 feet longer than the Chrysler Building is tall -- has its headaches, though. When the Queen Mary 2 docks in Manhattan on Thursday morning, it will be too long for the pier. David Gevanthor, a vice president at Cunard, joked that the Queen Mary 2 will be partly in New Jersey because it will extend more than 100 feet beyond its berth at the Passenger Ship Terminal.
 Maritime types like Mr. Miller cannot wait to see that. ''She's going to hang out in the river, which has never happened before,'' Mr. Miller said.
 The last time New York welcomed a too-long ship, the city lengthened its too-short pier. The year was 1911; the ship was the Olympic, and the carpenters added 75 feet of wood, Mr. Miller said. This time, a tugboat will patrol the Hudson River to keep other vessels at a distance as the Queen Mary 2 comes and goes.
 That is, assuming the Queen Mary 2 makes it under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. If the Queen Mary 2 were to sail under at high tide, the clearance would be only 13 feet. Indeed, the bridge influenced the shape of the ship. ''It looks squat and a little bit dumpy, and that's because of the Verrazano,'' Mr. Miller said. ''The funnel is flatter than it should be.'' From keel to black-and-red funnel is 236 feet.
 Capt. Paul Wright, who was at the helm last month when the Queen Mary 2 arrived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was not worried about scraping the Verrazano or about docking in New York. From the ship's bridge, a wide room with plate-glass windows where navigation charts appear on flat-screen computer monitors and the ship's moves are controlled with joysticks, he said that the QM2 handled better than the QE2.
 ''The QE2 needs good powerful tugs to bring her in, depending on the tide,'' Captain Wright explained. ''This one, we will have a tug standing by for the first time, but she would be quite capable of maneuvering in on her own.''
 If the weather is bad and the water is rough, there are always the bow thrusters, three large propellers. ''We can literally make the ship move sideways,'' he said. ''We can quite comfortably move the ship against a 25- to 30-knot wind.'' If the bow thrusters can be switched on. A malfunction in Lisbon last week delayed the ship's departure, but Cunard said the problem had been fixed.
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will welcome the ship on Thursday. Tomorrow, he is expected to announce that the cruise industry has agreed to pay additional port fees that will cover modernizing the Passenger Ship Terminal and adding a berth in Brooklyn. Last year, the city rejected a plan for a $100 million terminal at Pier 7 in Brooklyn.
 Tomorrow's announcement comes as cruise line officials worry that the Passenger Ship Terminal cannot handle all the traffic headed to New York. Carnival, the big cruise line that owns Cunard, has more than a dozen ships under construction. Royal Caribbean announced last year that it was moving three ships to Bayonne, N.J.
 ''Even before they built the Queen Mary 2, there were more and more of the ocean liners, the cruisers, leaving from New York,'' said Burchenal Green, the executive vice president of the National Maritime Historical Society. ''The Queen Elizabeth 2 was a start in helping to bring the cruisers and the ocean liners back, and I think the Queen Mary 2 will be significant to New York in the way that the QE2 was. If you remember 20 years ago, the whole New York harbor was sort of in decay.''
 The city says the cruise industry accounts for 3,320 jobs and adds almost $600 million to the city's economy. Forecasts that passenger volumes will double by 2014 have steamship buffs shaking their heads in wonder.
 ''We thought the age of the big superliner, and I know that sounds redundant, was over'' in the 1970's, Mr. Miller said. ''In 1980, National Geographic said that the QE2, at 70,000 tons, would be the last big ocean liner we'd ever see until there are floating hotels in outer space.''
 The QE2 is now the 79th largest ocean liner in the world, he said, and 100,000-ton liners are almost ordinary. The QM2 weighs 151,400 tons, which is about as much as 390 fully-loaded 747's, the 500-passenger airplanes that did as much as anything to displace ocean liners as the world's high-volume people carriers.
 But a 747 does not have 22 elevators opening on 17 decks; 14 bars and clubs; 6 restaurants; 5 outdoor swimming pools or a planetarium. A 747 does not have 708 staterooms with balconies, 281 interior staterooms looking out on a six-story atrium, 4 suites and 6 penthouses.
 Or 1,253 crew members who need to restock those personal necessities. How to recognize a crew member when the Queen Mary 2 is in port? ''That would be the person walking straight for the store that sells the fabric softener and the toothpaste,'' said David Dobbs, a waiter.

HEADLINE: Embroiled First Selectman Takes Leave

BYLINE: By JOE WOJTAS

 BODY:
STONINGTON residents were shocked three weeks ago when the popular First Selectman Peter N. Dibble was charged in connection with sexual misconduct involving a girl beginning when she was 10 years old.
 They had been even more surprised by Mr. Dibble's refusal to resign or take a leave of absence as he fights the charge of risk of injury to a minor that could send him to prison for up to 20 years and land him on the state's registry of sexual offenders. 
 But on Wednesday, Mr. Dibble, 59, told the Board of Selectmen that he would take a 30-day paid leave of absence effective immediately. 
 During that period Mr. Dibble, a Republican, and the town will negotiate a possible financial settlement in exchange for his resignation. Residents will have to vote to approve any settlement agreement that exceeds $20,000. Mr. Brown said he expected the settlement offer to be less than $100,000. 
 ''This was a very difficult decision for Peter to make,'' said Mr. Dibble's lawyer, Ronald Stevens. ''He was determined, though, to put the best interests of the town ahead of his.'' 
 Selectman William Brown will be the acting first selectman in Mr. Dibble's absence. 
 Mr. Brown said Mr. Dibble's leave of absence would end the ''media frenzy.''
 ''No town wants to go through this,'' Mr. Brown said after Wednesday's meeting. ''Waterbury went through this; Bridgeport went through this and the state is going through this with the governor. Maybe tonight we've got some closure.''
 Mr. Dibble had said he had no intention of leaving office and residents had discovered there was nothing in the town charter or state law that they could use to make him step down unless he is convicted and sent to prison.
 But that hasn't stopped them from trying. 
 When she learned about the details of the charge a few days after his arrest, Denise Donelin spent the entire day sitting in the lobby of Town Hall with three large signs calling on Mr. Dibble to resign. Mr. Dibble had to pass by the signs as he showed up for work as did hundreds of other people who visited Town Hall that day.
 Ms. Donelin said ''her blood boiled'' when she read that in the affidavit for his arrest Mr. Dibble accused the girl of being ''the instigator'' when the girl's family members confronted him about the allegation.
 ''I'm just an advocate for children. I guess I just don't want to see him get away with this,'' she said. ''People who work for him in Town Hall shouldn't have to look at him every day.'' 
 Possibly paving the way for Mr. Dibble's decision to take a leave, the Stonington Board of Finance voted on Tuesday to eliminate Mr. Dibble's $6,000 expense account for fiscal 2005 as well as a $2,335 raise that he had been scheduled to receive on July 1. Mr. Dibble, who was at the Tuesday meeting and insisted he had no intention of resigning or accepting a financial settlement to leave office, calmly listened and watched as the board voted.
 Minutes later, when the meeting concluded, Mr. Dibble said the effort to eliminate his raise and expense account came as a complete surprise. ''I was appalled that not one of them had the courage to pick up the phone and talk to me about this in advance,'' he said.
 The day after the details of the charge became public, Mr. Dibble's two colleagues on the Board of Selectmen, Mr. Brown and Peter Balestracci, told him he must resign at a selectmen's meeting. Both men said it was difficult for them to call for Mr. Dibble's resignation because they have been friends with him for many years. Mr. Balestracci grew up with Mr. Dibble in Mystic and Mr. Brown has been his running mate in past elections.
 ''In light of what you have been accused of, I don't think you can concentrate on performing your duties and responsibilities required by the position you hold,'' Mr. Balestracci told Mr. Dibble, who was sitting a few feet away. ''In light of what you have been accused of, I feel you have lost the faith and confidence of the people who have elected you.'' 
 Mr. Balestracci said morale in Town Hall has hit an all-time low and both he and Mr. Brown have received many angry calls from residents wanting Mr. Dibble to step down. 
 According to the affidavit for Mr. Dibble's arrest warrant, Stonington police received a complaint in December after the girl, now 13, told three friends at a sleepover that Mr. Dibble had kissed her with his mouth open and sucked her fingers on as many as 40 occasions over a three-year period that ended last summer. The State Department of Children and Families conducted its own investigation and said it substantiated charges of sexual abuse against Mr. Dibble. If Mr. Dibble is convicted under the sexual assault portion of the risk of injury statute he would have to register with the state's sex offender database. 
 According to the affidavit, Mr. Dibble admitted to the girl's mother that he kissed the girl with his mouth open, nibbled her fingers and cuddled her. He told investigators he never had an erection with the girl and said he did not consider the incidents a sexual matter. He said in the affidavit that he first talked to the girl about the kissing when she was 10 and later he talked with her mother about the kissing, which he said became more aggressive and prolonged. 
 Mr. Dibble and his lawyer, Mr. Stevens, have declined to comment about the allegations. Mr. Stevens said Mr. Dibble will ''vigorously contest'' the allegations in New London Superior Court, where he has entered a not guilty plea. 
 Mr. Brown, who also is chairman of the Republican Town Committee, said he asked Mr. Dibble to resign after reading what he called the ''distasteful'' allegations contained in the affidavit. Mr. Dibble, who is twice-divorced with no children and currently single, told him then he had no intentions of stepping down. 
 Some residents said the town will now be considered alongside communities such as Waterbury, where Mayor Philip Giordano is serving a 37-year prison sentence for sexually assaulting two pre-teen girls, and Bridgeport, where Mayor Joe Ganim is serving nine years on corruption charges. Last year, the General Assembly rejected a measure that would have allowed towns to remove mayors and first selectmen facing serious criminal charges. 
 Ms. Donelin said she would like the town to hold a referendum so residents can vote on whether Mr. Dibble should leave office.
 With letters and editorials in local newspapers urging him to resign, Ms. Donelin was among about 30 residents circulating a petition that calls on Mr. Dibble to resign. Ms. Donelin's daughter Lindsey is collecting signatures at Stonington High School, where last semester Mr. Dibble helped teach a class that encourages students to get involved in local government. Mr. Dibble stopped teaching the class after reports surfaced that he was being investigated.
 Mr. Dibble has served 10 years as first selectmen, six from 1981 to 1993 when he was a member of the Board of Selectmen. He then left to work in the administrations of governors Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and John G. Rowland, where he worked on intergovernmental issues as well as economic and community development. He came back to local politics in 2001 and has easily won the past two elections.

One angry resident, Denise Donelin, top right, organized a petition asking him to resign. Joan Driscoll signing the petition. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: ABSOLUTELY PREFAB

BYLINE: By Alastair Gordon. 
Alastair Gordon is the author of ''Beach Houses: Andrew Geller'' (Princeton Architectural Press).

 BODY:
Adam Kalkin's work explores an enigmatic zone in which art, architecture and mass-market consumerism converge in a quirky way. ''I love to watch the metamorphosis of a thing changing from a high-culture object to a low-culture pill that can be easily swallowed,'' he said one morning in March, as he led a television crew shooting a segment for the Fine Living Network through the steel cells of his patented Quik House, a prototype of his latest prefab design. (The house was the subject of a recent exhibition, ''Suburban House Kit,'' at Deitch Projects' Wooster Street gallery in New York.)
 Kalkin's house is made from recycled shipping containers, the kind you see in the dockyards of Brooklyn and Port Elizabeth, N.J. The basic Quik House kit, which costs $76,000, is a 2,000-square-foot structure made of five modified containers in a simple building-block arrangement: three 40-footers rest on two 20-footers. It comes in orange or natural Rust Bloom and can be trucked to the site and erected in a week, according to the designer and the brochure, which comes with the kit and shows a faceless couple standing with a faceless dog in front of the boxlike structure. Optional features include skylights, $1,500 for three; a stainless-steel kitchen, $24,000; and mahogany sliding doors, $4,000 (figures don't include the price of the building site or construction costs). 
 For this prototype, five containers were artfully welded to create a two-story pavilion, complete with a cozy fire burning in a stainless-steel hearth. The central living area was furnished with orange couches and a kitchen island equipped with a Viking range and dishwasher. Floors were covered with custom-designed carpeting by the artist Jim Isermann.
 The idea of the mail-order-kit house has been part of the American dream since 1908, when houses by mail were first offered in the Sears, Roebuck & Company catalog. More recently, there have been efforts to adapt steel containers to a similar kind of prefabricated housing. Kalkin has been investigating their potential since 1992; in 1993 he used one in a performance-art piece, ''Addiction.'' Since then, he has worked with them in seven different projects, with the goal of arriving at a mass-market commodity. ''You confront a whole other set of problems when you try to turn an artistic thing into a multiple commercial product,'' he confessed.
 But it makes sense: containers are readily available and virtually indestructible. They can be easily stacked and transferred from ship to truck to building site. They come in an assortment of sizes and are relatively cheap: a container 20 feet by 8 feet costs about $1,500, while, oddly, a 40-foot-long container costs even less, about $1,200. Some people are attracted by their stark industrial beauty -- their rusting corrugation and the hieroglyphic markings stenciled on their sides.
 While Kalkin admires their structural integrity and affordability, he is equally intrigued by how they plug into what he calls the ''global economic cult.''
 ''These things have been sitting on ships all over the world, carrying God knows what,'' he said. ''They have all of this veiled mystery.'' For a vacation house in coastal Maine, he used 12 shipping containers arranged in a double-T formation. For an earlier prefab project -- ''$99,000 House'' -- Kalkin used three containers as a structural core.
 To relieve the sense of coldness and claustrophobia, he removes the end panels or cuts an opening where one is needed. ''You just take a welding torch and do whatever you want,'' he said. The prototype has large window openings and three skylights.
 Although his work grows out of the edgy milieu of the New York art scene, Kalkin is marketing his houses to a mass audience.
 A version of the Quik House will most likely be built on the outskirts of Utrecht, the Netherlands, for a program (partly sponsored by the government) that invites artists to respond to housing issues. Kalkin is also developing 40-by-40-foot versions of the house to be used by the United Nations for refugee shelter.
 He has also started to design variations on the basic prototype for private clients, including the fashion designer Cynthia Rowley. ''It's so simple and resourceful an idea, like making a silk purse out of a sow's ear,'' Rowley said. ''You just add friends, and you have an instant utopia.''

 Precious cargo: for the SoHo show, the Quik House was customized with skylights and mahogany sliding doors, carpeting by Jim Isermann, a video installation by Aernout Mik and a futuristic ''garden'' by Tobias Rehberger. (PHOTOGRAPHS BY AMY ECKERT)

HEADLINE: MORE JOBS IN STATE

BYLINE: By Jess Bruder

 BODY:
New Jersey gained 12,900 jobs in March, increasing the number of nonfarm payroll jobs in the state to more than four million, the highest employment level since December 2000, Labor Commissioner Albert G. Kroll announced on Wednesday. 
Leading this growth were professional and business services, which added 6,700 jobs, and trade, transportation, and utilities, which added 5,000 jobs. Their gains offset losses in manufacturing and construction, which shrunk by 2,000 and 1,700 jobs, respectively. The March unemployment rate was 5.2 percent, down from 5.4 percent in February. LENGTH: 333 words

HEADLINE: Holland American Ship To Stop in New London

BYLINE: By JOE WOJTAS

 BODY:
It may not be St. Thomas or Nassau, but city and tourism officials hope New London will soon be a don't-miss port for the growing number of ships sailing along the New England coast each summer.
 On May 14, the Holland America ship Maasdam will stop in New London for about seven hours with its 1,200 passengers and return in October. 
 Some people may wonder why ships would stop in New London, a small, former whaling port with a struggling downtown and no big tourist attractions. 
 Not George Cassidy.
 ''New London is the perfect place for a cruise ship to visit,' said Mr. Cassidy, the executive director of the state's Cruise Ship Task Force. 
 He said that's because Mystic Seaport, Mystic Aquarium and the Submarine Force Museum in Groton are just a short bus ride away. 
 There is Fort Griswold in Groton, the newly refurbished Fort Trumbull in New London, the Essex Steam Train and Riverboat, Gillette Castle in East Haddam and the Florence Griswold Museum in Old Lyme. He said trips will probably not be offered to the two nearby casinos.
 Mr. Cassidy said it all appeals to veteran cruise ship passengers who have want more than just Caribbean beaches and are looking for trips that focus on history and culture. 
 He said the visit is expected to bring about $100,000 to the local economy.
 Peter Glankoff , the director of communications for Mystic Seaport, said the area will keep the passengers busy.
 ''New London is the port of entry for the whole Mystic region,'' he said. ''There's more than enough for people to do right here.''
 This will be the second time a cruise ship has visited New London. The smaller Regal Empress visited two years ago.
 The Maasdam will be greeted by tugboats spraying water, a 14-gun salute from Fort Trumbull and music from a fife and drum corps.''The future will all depend on how this port call goes. Cruise ships rely on feedback from their passengers,'' Mr. Cassidy said. 
 ''The other cruise lines will be watching very closely what happens here.'' JOE WOJTAS

HEADLINE: Digging Up Low Web Fares

BYLINE: By BOB TEDESCHI. 
E-mail: tedeschi@nytimes.com

 BODY:
INGRID AGUIRRE HAPPOLDT, a program officer for a nonprofit organization in Oakland, Calif., no longer surfs for bargain fares the way she once did.
 Ms. Happoldt said she used to chase down bargain fares promoted in e-mail newsletters or ads, ''but when you actually went to the airline site and put in the dates you wanted, the fare always ended up being different from what was advertised, and you're kind of like, 'Huh!'''
 Indeed, you could argue that it's more of a waste of time pursuing fare sales online than it was a few years ago. Fully 75 percent of the adult population of the United States is now online, compared with less than half in 2000, according to Nielsen//NetRatings, a company that measures Internet use. And with every passing year, more of them are willing to pull out their credit cards and compete for the cheap flights with other Internet users. 
 Meanwhile, fare sales are more fleeting than ever. Henry Harteveldt, a travel analyst with the consulting firm Forrester Research, said fare sales generally last three days, compared with five years ago, when they typically lasted a week.
 Still, for those who find news of fare bargains through e-mail messages, newspaper ads or online scuttlebutt, Web sites offer an increasing array of features that help you waste as little time as possible finding out if the fares actually apply to travel dates you might want. But you have to know where to look, and often must waste lots of clicks.
 For instance, in late February I surfed to the Travel Bargains section of America Online's Hartford-New Haven city guide, which lists fare sales for various airports in the area. There, I found a sale fare of $150 round trip from Hartford to San Francisco on American.
 I clicked through to American and typed in dates that conformed to the fare rules on AOL's Travel Bargains page, and crossed my fingers -- in vain, it turned out. The seats American had allotted to the sale rate were apparently sold out. I was quoted a fare of $536, and I had no way of quickly figuring out how to find the sale fare -- on American's Web site, at least.
 Instead, I logged onto Travelocity. There, I selected the Flexible Dates option when typing in my destination and arrival cities, and chose a range of travel dates. Rather than returning a page of specific flights, the site displayed the best possible fares for that date range, starting with the $150 round-trip option.
 Clicking on that fare yielded a calendar showing me the departure dates for which the fare was available in theory. I spent nearly 10 minutes clicking on the ''available'' dates, only to have the screen refresh with a new calendar telling me that those dates were no longer available. I gave up, figuring word had spread so quickly that I was simply too late.

Results at Last
 The next morning I visited the Travel Bargains page again, and saw the American fare was now $145. I immediately clicked through to Travelocity's fare calendar, and after trying a few weekend dates that were sold out, I hit paydirt: a Friday-through-Monday trip to San Francisco for $176 (after taxes and fees).
 Travelocity's fare calendar is not unique. Expedia and Orbitz also provide calendar options, for those who are more interested in finding inexpensive fares than traveling on specific dates. For each of Expedia's Featured Travel Deals listed on the home page, the site offers a page with a flight booking box. When you scan the mouse over the calendar icon within that box, a calendar shows available dates for the sale.
 Both the Travelocity and Expedia calendars can be misleading, though, since they do not show the actual fares available at that moment. Travelocity's calendar shows dates that conform to the fare sale rules, not the dates with available seats. As I found, it takes a little clicking and some luck to land a bargain.
 On Orbitz, meanwhile, clicking the Flexible Dates button in the air fare search box leads to a page with a host of options, including, among other things, a search for low weekend fares only. The fares shown here are actually available, which explains why, at first glance, they seem higher than those shown on the calendars of Orbitz's competitors. (A My Dates Are Flexible button on Expedia lists each day's fares on a calendar.) 
 Among airline Web sites, Southwest.com is among the most user friendly for those looking to capitalize on a fare sale. Southwest's Shortcut feature, available on the top right-hand side of the home page, presents travelers with a color-coded calendar showing which prices you'll pay for certain travel dates. Promotional fares, like $99 one-way fares for coast-to-coast flights, are typically unavailable Thursday, Friday, Sunday and Monday.

Exceptions to the Rule
 And though some travelers no longer even look for bargain fares on those days, there are more exceptions than you might think, according to Jon Douglas, senior editor of SmarterLiving.com, a travel-related informational site. ''For domestic flights, Tuesday, Wednesday and Saturday could be the cheapest,'' he said. ''For airlines like AirTran, it's every day but Friday and Sunday. But if Delta matches an AirTran sale, they'll follow those rules. It's really all over the map.''
 To help consumers find the cheap fares quickly, SmarterLiving.com distributes, at no charge, weekly e-mail newsletters compiling last-minute air fare sales for more than 80 cities, as well as another newsletter covering longer-running deals on airline tickets, rental cars and other travel products.
 The SmarterLiving Web site is itself useful for finding cheap fares, but again, be prepared to waste clicks at times, chasing fare bargains that no longer exist, or that have such limited availability that they might as well not exist. It's a problem that online travel agencies battle constantly. Since their systems do not monitor prices for routes continuously, they must hear from the airline, a customer or an alert employee about a fare selling out.
 And even though it sometimes feel as if Web sites are baiting customers with cheap flights, only to switch them to higher fares, analysts said online travel companies are careful not to run afoul of the law in this regard. Bill Mosley, a spokesman for United States Department of Transportation, said that airlines promoting fare sales must generally make available 10 percent of their seats for that route for the advertised price. ''That doesn't mean there has to be any seats on a specific flight or day or aircraft,'' he said. ''We look at the whole course of the promotion.''
 Mr. Mosley said airlines have complied with that policy in recent years. The last carriers cited for failing to make a reasonable number of sale seats available were US Airways and American Trans Air, both in 1997.
 With such a slim number of seats available during sales, and so many bargain hunters scanning the Internet, Web sites are left to do their best in removing promotions, while acknowledging they sometimes fall short. Mr. Douglas said SmarterLiving.com is updated frequently throughout the day. But he added, ''it's still possible not to get what you're looking for, because availability changes in real time.''

LENGTH: 2066 words

HEADLINE: Steinbeck, at Last, Welcomed Home

BYLINE: By DEAN E. MURPHY. 
DEAN E. MURPHY is chief of the San Francisco bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
THE city of Salinas and the surrounding valley about 100 miles south of San Francisco are commonly known as Steinbeck Country, the consequence of an uneasy reconciliation between the Nobel laureate in the years since his death and the place where he was born and raised.
 During his lifetime, John Steinbeck and his hometown became so estranged that the author once objected to the naming of a local school building after him because he figured it would be an excuse to cuss his name. Theirs was a troubled and mostly unforgiving relationship, one with spells of love and hate and most emotions in between.
 ''Steinbeck was never popular with the growers here,'' said Basil E. Mills, the founder of one of the large farming businesses that dominate the Salinas Valley. ''It is a unique marriage on both sides.'' 
 The museum built here to honor Steinbeck has ''national'' in its title, but the visitor should not be distracted by the suggestion. The National Steinbeck Center is best explored and appreciated as a local place, an institution conceived by and for the people of this conflicted rural region where Steinbeck's books were burned and where he was made to feel unwelcome for much of his life.
 The center is not officially called a museum because it was always intended to be much more. Last year it played host to 265 community events, from Rotary Club meetings to wedding receptions. It is the keystone of a revitalization plan that is expected to bring movie theaters and a hotel to the sagging north end of Main Street, which in Steinbeck's youth was mostly swampland. Already, the modern 40,000-square-foot brick and glass center draws 90,000 visitors each year to a downtown once left for dead.
 Last fall, just after the center's fifth anniversary, a $5.6 million wing opened with exhibits about agriculture in the Salinas Valley. Fund-raising begins soon for another proposed expansion, a $3 million wing with classrooms and art galleries that will adjoin the spacious glass central hall and pair of windowless exhibit wings. Though some of the money for the center has come from the city's redevelopment agency, a good chunk has been donated by local residents and businesses, including some that would have nothing to do with Steinbeck before his death in 1968.
 ''It is a community institution that people care about, and they are willing to mix it up and get their hands on it,'' said Alice Parman, an independent museum consultant in Eugene, Ore., who researched the center's exhibits. ''There is a lot of ownership and caring about this place.''
 Steinbeck was born in Salinas in 1902 and didn't move away until he went to college, and then only for a brief stint. He knew Salinas as his backyard and drew upon its colorful townspeople for some of his most inspired writing. Though Steinbeck advanced well beyond the valley in both his life and work, eventually settling in New York and Sag Harbor, he was so rooted to this place that he asked in his dying days that his remains be returned here.
 ''His whole sense of home becomes this valley that for him has a moral dynamic,'' said Susan G. Shillinglaw, the director of the Center for Steinbeck Studies at San Jose State University, a collection of Steinbeck papers and memorabilia in the Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Library, a public university library about an hour's drive north of here.
 ''Think of all the people trying to find a home in Steinbeck,'' she said. ''George and Lennie, the Joads, and Mack and the boys in 'Cannery Row.' They are all trying to find a place for themselves. That is what American history is about: traveling to find a place to live, that whole sense of going West and discovering not-Eden.''
 At the entrance to the main Steinbeck exhibit here, a floor-to-ceiling map of the Salinas Valley displays the geographic lineage of his books, from an apple pickers' strike in nearby Watsonville that figures prominently in ''In Dubious Battle'' to the ranches of Soledad that provide the rural backdrop for George and Lennie in ''Of Mice and Men.''
 As the exhibit winds through Steinbeck's literary life, capturing everything from his lackluster success as a Broadway playwright to his venture as a speechwriter for Adlai Stevenson, it gives the sense that he rarely felt far from home.
 ''I think I would like to write the story of this whole valley, of the little towns and all the farms and ranches in the wilder hills,'' one display quotes from a letter Steinbeck wrote to a friend in 1933. ''I can see how I would like to do it so that it would be the valley of the world.''
 Even as a teenager, another display reveals, Steinbeck escaped to his upstairs bedroom in the Queen Anne-style home where he was born on Central Avenue, just a short walk from where the Steinbeck Center now stands, and wrote pieces about his hometown that he mailed to magazines.
 ''I never knew what happened to them because I never put a return address on them,'' Steinbeck told an interviewer.
 The meticulously restored house, a stately two-story frame structure with a turret and steeply pitched roof, is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. It is run by volunteers as a restaurant for lunch (much of their business comes from visitors to the center). The fixed-price menu usually includes something named after the author -- the Steinbeck Green Salad or Steinbeck Ice Tea (a mix of tea, lemonade and raspberry) -- and the walls are decorated with family photographs. In a basement gift shop is the headboard from the bed on which Steinbeck was born, and in a locked bookcase, first editions of several of his works.
 As a native son with a discerning eye and a nose for news, Steinbeck became privy to many of Salinas's darkest secrets. By sharing them with the world in books like ''East of Eden,'' he was seen by many here to have violated an unspoken trust. His writing was particularly unpopular among the well-to-do, like the big agricultural interests that built their wealth on the backs of fieldworkers, the unsung heroes of Steinbeck's world.
 ''Salinas was never a pretty town,'' Steinbeck wrote in 1955 in the magazine Holiday. ''It took a darkness from the swamps. The high gray fog hung over it and the ceaseless wind blew up the valley, cold and with a kind of desolate monotony. The mountains on both sides of the valley were beautiful, but Salinas was not and we knew it. Perhaps that is why a kind of violent assertiveness, an energy like the compensation for sin grew up in the town.''
 Salinas is now bigger (population 150,000) and still unsightly. Some of its farmland has been planted with strip malls and a Wal-Mart. The cemetery where Steinbeck is buried, the serene-sounding Garden of Memories that figures in ''East of Eden,'' is on a noisy thoroughfare with a thrift shop and auto-parts store across the street. A yellow Denny's sign blots the horizon in the tailpipe haze beyond the graves.
 There are still remnants of the Salinas that pulled copies of Steinbeck's Pulitzer Prize-winning book about the Depression, ''The Grapes of Wrath,'' from the library and burned them. At least one grower still refuses to donate to the Steinbeck Center because of lingering hard feelings. But more and more, Salinas sees itself as a grown-up town that has chosen to honor Steinbeck, the Nobel Prize winner for literature in 1962, with a multimillion-dollar monument.
 ''Each generation has mellowed,'' said Mr. Mills, the grower, who is president of the center's board. ''Most recognize this was something in the past. We realized, too, that just as times change, conditions change. Some of the things Steinbeck wrote about, we very well deserved to rethink. Some others, he has taken some poetic license.''
 Even so, there are still efforts to balance Steinbeck's influence more than three decades after his death. The center's new agricultural wing has been characterized in news accounts as a concession to the valley's farming interests, though Mr. Mills said that was not true. Though housed in the Steinbeck Center, the exhibits are not about the author or his works. Their content was determined after the museum convened focus groups of growers, agricultural businesses and field workers.
 ''It has received good comments from most people,'' Mr. Mills said.
 The interactive displays trace the valley's agricultural boom, which took off with the valley's irrigation in the 1890's, and allow visitors to vote with a bar-code scanner for their favorite vegetable (on a recent day, iceberg lettuce was slightly ahead of spinach and cauliflower).
 Still, agriculture in the Salinas Valley remains a sensitive subject. A committee has been set up by the center to consider complaints and suggestions. When growers grumbled that quotations in the displays identified them by name but did not do the same for field hands, the committee added the names of the field hands.
 Ms. Shillinglaw, the Steinbeck scholar, said that in some ways the social dynamic dominated by agricultural interests in the Salinas Valley has remained frozen in time. When she lectures about Steinbeck and the valley, Ms. Shillinglaw said, she makes certain to read from his account in 1955 of the social pecking order in ''Always Something to Do in Salinas.''
 ''Sugar People might never have got any place socially if lettuce had not become the green gold of the Valley,'' he wrote in Holiday magazine. ''Now we had a new set of upstarts: Lettuce People. Sugar People joined Cattle People in looking down their noses. These Lettuce People had Carrot People to look down on and these in turn felt odd about associating with Cauliflower People.''
 A few years earlier, when Steinbeck wrote ''East of Eden,'' he drew upon the biblical story of Cain and Abel to explain some of the darkness of his hometown. If he were alive today, Steinbeck might turn to the New Testament to help tell his own story. There, in Matthew, an adult Jesus returned home as a prophet, only to face an audience that ''took offense at him.''
 ''But Jesus said to them, 'Only in his hometown and in his own house is a prophet without honor.''' 

If you go
 The National Steinbeck Center, 1 Main Street, Salinas, Calif., (831) 796-3833, www.steinbeck.org; is open daily 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; general admission $10.95. The annual Steinbeck Festival, (831) 775-4721, will be held at the center Aug. 5 to 8 and has two themes: ''The Politics of Steinbeck'' and ''Steinbeck and the Environment.'' Tickets are $75. Literary bus tours to Monterey and other nearby sites cost $60 extra last year.
 John Steinbeck's grave is about two miles from the National Steinbeck Center at Garden of Memories Memorial Park, 768 Abbott Street, Salinas, (831) 422-6417. It is open daily 8 a.m. to a half hour after dusk. Steinbeck is buried in the plot of his grandparents, Samuel and Elizabeth Hamilton; follow the metal Steinbeck arrow on the cemetery road. 

Getting There
 By car, the trip from San Francisco takes about two and a half hours. Take 101 South to the Main Street exit in Salinas, continue north on Main Street and follow signs. Parking in the municipal lot across the street is free with a two-hour maximum. 
 By Amtrak, (800) 872-7245 or tickets.amtrak.com, the Coast Starlight from Emeryville (just across the bridge to Oakland) departs at 8:20 a.m. and arrives in Salinas at 11:48 a.m. The return leaves Salinas at 6:36 p.m. and arrives in Emeryville at 10:02 p.m. Round-trip adult fare is about $42.
 Greyhound, greyhound.com, has a bus that leaves San Francisco at 6 a.m. and arrives in Salinas at 10:05 a.m. A return bus leaves Salinas at 4:45 p.m. and arrives in San Francisco at 9:05 p.m., with another leaving 7:05 p.m., arriving 10 p.m. Round-trip fare is about $40. The train station and bus terminal are in downtown Salinas, within walking distance of the Steinbeck Center. 

Restaurants
 One Main Street Cafe, (831) 775-4738, www.restauranteur.com/onemain, is in the National Steinbeck Center building and serves California cuisine and Monterey County wine. Most menu items from $7 to $10. Open daily from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. 
 The Steinbeck House and Restaurant, 132 Central Avenue, (831) 424-2735, infopoint.com/mry/orgs/steinbeck, is a short walk from the museum. Open Monday through Saturday from 11:30 a.m. to 2 p.m. Reservations recommended. A meal from the fixed-price menu, with beverage and tax, is $11.50 a person. Dessert is $4 extra. DEAN E. MURPHY
